The Government's £12bn plan to turn the London Underground into a private-public partnership by March 2001 could be undermined by its failure to clear considerable safety problems.

The Health and Safety Executive announced last night that it was planning an audit of the LU in December to ensure that safety conditions were being met. It could not accept any plans for change unless it was "completely happy" with the safety case.

The transfer to the private sector, which still leaves the state exercising overall control, would have to be abandoned if safety was at stake.

The HSE said that it was still looking for improvements in the new safety regime. It said it had learnt lessons from the Paddington crash last October, caused partly by the re-alignment of the track outside the station in the lead up to privatisation.

LU has already been singled out by the HSE for its approach to safety. Railway inspectors have criticised senior LU managers for a diffident attitude to the issue.

The public's perception of the underground - one of the biggest in the world - is that it is detoriating. There have been several high profile incidents in the past few weeks, culminating in a serious case earlier this week when some 2,000 people were trapped on the Central line for two hours without fresh air.

The HSE said last night that it was "extremely concerned", particularly as LU was committed to getting passengers out within 30 minutes following an incident.

LU later said that the target was self-imposed, following the King's Cross fire in 1989. The HSE also criticised LU for waiting for an hour before calling the fire brigade. In reponse LU said it had in fact waited only 37 minutes. Even then it had delayed the call because it felt it could cope with the incident itself.

Critics of the HSE say that it is only taking a tough stance against LU because of the Paddington crash. It is expected that the HSE will be criticised for not taking tough action with Railtrack and the train operating companies for signals passed at danger. It has already admitted that its inspection procedures could be improved.

The HSE also said that new rolling stock on the underground was breaking down, and was unreliable. LU replied that the system was performing satisfactorily.

The government is still pouring money into the LU. The Jubilee line extension is not finished, nine months after it was started.

Remedial work is still being carried out at Westminster station, where the threat of water seeping in, has not yet been averted.

The uncharacteristic fury expressed by Kofi Annan, the UN secretary general, over this week's killing of three aid workers in West Timor was fully justified. Thanks to the New York summit of world leaders, Mr Annan was able to inform Indonesia's President Abdurrahman Wahid of his disgust in person. The security situation in the Indonesian-run province, where thousands of pro-Jakarta militiamen still roam unchecked a year after neighbouring East Timor's independence referendum provoked an orgy of killing, was totally unacceptable, Mr Annan said. His criticism was echoed by both Bill Clinton and Tony Blair, and by Sadako Ogata, the UNHCR chief, whose agency has logged over 100 attacks on its personnel in West Timor in the past 12 months. The evacuation of remaining UN staff now exposes 120,000 refugees to great hardship amid reports yesterday of new militia murders.

But for all the understandable anger, such protests are unlikely to have much practical impact. In truth, Mr Wahid exercises little or no direct control over events in West Timor or, for that matter, in several other troubled regions of his fragmented country. His decision to send in troop reinforcements may only make matters worse, given that elements within the army are intimately linked to the Timor militias - just as they are deeply implicated in continuing anti-separatist and ethnic and religious violence in places as far apart as Aceh, Sulawesi, Ambon and Papua. Mr Wahid's sacking of the deeply suspect armed forces chief, General Wiranto, has not enabled him to rein in a military that grew accustomed to autonomy of action (and money-making opportunities) during ex-president Suharto's dictatorship.

Demands by human rights groups that commanders, soldiers and militiamen responsible for the East Timor atrocities be called to account have so far brought forth an official list of a mere 19 suspects who may or may not face prosecution. Gen Wiranto is not among them. External pressure for an independent, international war crimes tribunal has been rebuffed. The Jakarta parliament, where Mr Wahid's grip is also tenuous, has meanwhile passed a constitutional amendment allowing the granting of retrospective amnesties for rights abuses. Mr Suharto, on trial for corruption and pleading Pinochet-like incapacity, has for his part already been assured of a presidential pardon should he be found guilty.

Since winning office last October, Mr Wahid has struggled to make his mark, hindered in part by the detached attitude of his deputy, Megawati Sukarnoputri, whom many Indonesians felt was unfairly denied the presidency, but also by his own policy vagueness, indecision, and penchant for foreign travel. An ambitious cabinet reshuffle last month seems to have failed to reboot his administration; indeed, it led to a run on the rupiah. Although the IMF this week readied the latest $400m tranche of a $5bn bail-out, Indonesia's economic position remains dangerously fraught. When this is taken alongside Mr Wahid's evident political weakness and the chaotic security situation, it is little wonder that there is renewed speculation in Jakarta about a fresh government crisis, plots and coups, and regional concern that Indonesia as a unified democracy is drifting towards disintegration.

All of which instability and uncertainty is bad news indeed for the fledgling, penniless nation of East Timor, at present under UN administration but due to take charge of its own affairs by the end of next year. The trauma of its birth may be very far from over.

The embattled Republican presidential candidate George W Bush has been forced to respond to a chorus of party criticism and a run of bad poll results by re-energising his campaign style and giving his slogans a face-lift in the contest with the Democrat Al Gore.

Mr Bush has decided to increase the tempo of what has sometimes seemed an unduly leisurely schedule. Instead he now intends to be seen getting in among the voters more, cutting down on set-piece speeches in favour of more glad-handing, and campaigning on a new theme of "Real Plans for Real People."

"I've got to get out and talk to people, and I'm going to do a lot of it," Mr Bush said in Pennsylvania yesterday. "I'm going to tell you what I think, and let the political chips fall where they may."

Mr Bush has decided to redefine himself as the underdog in the race with Mr Gore, who has drawn level and even moved ahead of him for the first time in some recent opinion polls. The move echoes a change of direction in Mr Bush's campaign for the Republican nomination earlier this year after John McCain defeated him in the New Hampshire primary.

Mr Bush has also signalled that he wants to extricate himself from the cul-de-sac he got himself into over the planned series of debates with Mr Gore later in the autumn. In a U-turn from the position he adopted as recently as Monday, Mr Bush has reopened negotiations with Mr Gore on the debate schedule.

Criticism of the Bush campaign from within the party has focused on a range of perceived failings, including the strategy towards the debates. Other issues include the use of negative advertising, the failure to make the case for Mr Bush's $1.3 trillion (£900bn) tax cut plan, the lacklustre performance of Mr Bush's running-mate Dick Cheney, and the tight control exercised by Mr Bush's Texas-based team in Austin.

But with the polls showing that Mr Bush's lead of a few weeks ago has now evaporated, the Republican challenger is eager to shore up his support by claiming that he is facing the fight of his political life.

"This is going to be a tight race," Mr Bush said. "I guess my supporters wanted it to be a runaway. The vice-president is running a strong race, but so am I. I am under no illusions and neither should our supporters be. I am the underdog - I sure am."

Mr Bush tried to laugh off several days of increasingly vocal criticisms of his campaign from within his own party. "That's Washington," he told reporters in Michigan. "That's the place where you find people getting ready to jump out of the foxholes before the first shell is fired."

Asked why he has decided to change tack by going more informal, Mr Bush responded: "Well, it's a better picture."

What is officially described as a campaign "retooling" comes as three new polls showed Mr Gore either tied with Mr Bush or ahead of him. A Zogby poll has Mr Gore leading by 46% to Mr Bush's 40%, while the first of a series of Gallup three-day tracking polls has Mr Gore up by 47% to 44%. A Washington Post poll shows the two men level on 47% each.

The latest poll in one of the key states in the election also shows Mr Gore taking the lead in Missouri by 45% to 41%.

Mr Bush's slide in the polls in the past two weeks has provoked a mood of near panic among some of his supporters. "There's no doubt about it. There's real worry about the general state of things," said the conservative campaigner William Bennett, a former education secretary. "There's nervousness that was not there before."

"The biggest mistake we can make is to try to be all things to all people," the Missouri congressman John Kasich said.

"I'm at a loss to explain the rather significant change in the polling numbers," Tom Ridge, governor of Pennsylvania, said.

The UN's battered reputation as a peacekeeper suffered another blow yesterday after disclosures of massive corruption on the part of the Nigerian element of the UN force in Sierra Leone.

An internal UN report about the Nigerian force brutally exposes the gap between the peacekeeping ideals expressed by world leaders at the millennium summit in New York this week and the reality on the ground in the conflict zones.

The focus of the summit, which ended yesterday, was on making peacekeeping forces more efficient and more tightly-controlled, primarily in Africa, following the disaster in Rwanda that led to genocide and the debacle in Sierra Leone that saw 500 UN soldiers being taken hostage.

The UN report on the Nigerian force in Sierra Leone reinforces the need for haste in pushing through the reforms.

It raises questions about the effectiveness of multinational forces and whether soldiers from round the world can work together for a common aim. The report was written by the Indian commander, Major General Vijay Kumar Jetley, who complained repeatedly about how he and his troops were denigrated by the Nigerians. There has been strife too between the Nigerians and British troops.

The alternative to a multinational force from continents round the world is a regional force. But the Nigerian performance in Sierra Leone also calls that into question.

The British defence secretary, Geoff Hoon, and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, supported the idea of regional peacekeeping forces, especially for conflicts such as the one in Sierra Leone. But the fear now is that if the Nigerians behaved so badly as part of a multinational force, they would be even worse if they were the main force operating in the west African country.

Sierra Leone is the biggest UN peacekeeping operation at present, with troops from around the world, and with moves to increase their number from 13,000 to 20,000. Nigeria, with 6,000 troops in the force, would like to have overall control and increase its contingent.

The report is an embarrassment to the Nigerian president, Olusegun Obasanjo, who wants to establish his country as the regional power. Mr Obasanjo, who was at the UN summit yesterday, has gone a long way towards improving Nigeria's image after years of dictatorship. But his efforts are being undone by his army. According to the UN report, the Nigerian army has obstructed peace moves in Sierra Leone because its officers and men are getting rich through illegally trading in diamonds.

The report supports a stream of complaints in the Sierra Leone capital, Freetown, about the Nigerian force. Reports from diverse sources claimed that the Nigerian army was heavily involved in diamonds, false passports, drug-smuggling and other illegal activities. Nigeria is one of the biggest drug centres in Africa and the allegation was that Sierra Leone provided a useful transition point for the shipment of drugs from Nigeria to Europe.

A by-product of this was that the Nigerian army supplied drugs to the Revolutionary United Front rebels, whose ill-disciplined troops have heavy drug habits that go part of the way to explaining the ferocity of their attacks on civilians.

Many of the claims could not be substantiated because they came from the RUF. But others were more credible, such as a pilot working out of Freetown's Lunghi airport who claimed to have knowledge of heavy drug trafficking.

At the heart of it all are Sierra Leone's diamonds. In return for drugs, the Nigerians allegedly receive from the rebels rough diamonds, which are easily sold in Antwerp and Tel Aviv.

The story of the UN is about a chasm between the high ideals at headquarters and the chaos and corruption on the ground.

Gen Jetley complained that the Nigerians put national interest before the good of the UN force. That may be true. But there are many cases of multinational forces co-existing: grumbling, as soldiers do, but getting on with the job, in the Balkans, the Middle East and elsewhere.

The issue in Sierra Leone may be partly one of personality, with Gen Jetley using the report to settle scores with the Nigerians.

The report has to be seen in the context of internal politicking within the UN force in Freetown. The Nigerians resent the fact that they were not given command of the force. The Indians, British and other members of the force would like to see the Nigerians go home, or at the very least ensure that no more arrive.

But troops for UN operations are not that easy to find. Replacing the 6,000 Nigerians would be difficult. The crux is whether they help or obstruct a move towards peace.

Corruption in armies is commonplace in Africa. Against the corruption has to be balanced the fact that the Nigerians are one of the most effective fighting forces in Sierra Leone, with the most success in taking on the rebels.

A reluctant acceptance of some level of corruption would be regarded as worthwhile by the UN if it was coupled with successful suppression of the RUF and a restoration of peace.

Profit over peace

The following are extracts from the report accusing Nigerian officers and officials of colluding with the RUF rebels in Sierra Leone, written by Major-General Vijay Jetley, the embattled commander of the UN peacekeeping force there

The Nigerian army was interested in staying in Sierra Leone due to massive benefits they were getting from illegal diamond mining

Brigadier-General Maxwell Khobe was commonly known as the "Ten Million man" : it is alleged that he received up to $10m (£6.6m) to permit the activities of RUF. The [West African intervention] force commander Major-General Kpamber was also involved.

It is understood that a tacit understanding was reached between the RUF and [the Nigerians] of non-interference in each other's activities. Protecting Nigerian interests was paramount even if it meant scuttling the peace process

To this end the special representative [of the UN in Sierra Leone, Oluyemi Adeniji] and the deputy force commander cultivated the RUF leadership, especially Foday Sankoh, behind my back

The Mission Directive given to me... directly conflicted with the interests of not only the warring factions but also of the major players in the diamond racket like Liberia and Nigeria. As an Indian, and having no hidden agenda to promote, I became a victim of the machinations of these countries.

In exile and in war, Yasser Arafat has personified his people's aspirations through four turbulent decades and today, with the Palestinians closer to regaining statehood than at any time since 1948, he will take another historic decision: to invite the wrath of Israel and the US by declaring independence next week, or to wait.

Mr Arafat's appearance before the Palestine Liberation Organisation's central council in Gaza city this weekend follows another difficult choice, his refusal during talks with President Clinton on the sidelines of the UN millennium summit in New York this week, to yield on the Palestinians' claim to Jerusalem.

But after giving the council's 127 members his version of what transpired at New York, Mr Arafat is expected to urge a postponement of any unilateral declaration of a state until November 15 at the earliest.

This latest delay - Mr Arafat held off such a declaration in May last year - is in part intended to blunt condemnation of the Palestinian leader as the villain of the peace process for his refusal to give Israel sovereignty of Islamic and Christian holy places in those parts of Jerusalem it has occupied since 1967.

"He will sell it to the world, to Europe and America, to show his flexibility," said an Arafat adviser, Mamdoh Nofal. "It is not so important for Mr Arafat to declare on this date, if there is no real change in his position as leader, or in the condition of his people. He has many of the elements of a state. We have 36,000 military men with weapons. We have flags, radio, television, ministries, and a legislative council."

But there are reasons other than his image for Mr Arafat not to declare statehood. One of them is that he does not have the land for a viable state - his forces have exclusive control of only 40% of the West Bank and Gaza - or the finances.

The Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, has threatened to retaliate against any unilateral declaration by annexing territory and imposing a blockade on an economy that is wholly dependent on Israel.

Another restraint is the lack of support for statehood now, as the Palestinian leader discovered during a fortnight of flying around world capitals after his peace talks with Mr Barak ended inconclusively at Camp David in July despite much direct involvement by President Bill Clinton.

The US and most European countries are among those opposing a unilaterial declaration at present. "Mr Arafat knows that he struck hard at Mr Clinton and Mr Barak when he refused their plans and he knows they are so angry and they are waiting around the corner to ambush him and take revenge. So he will not give them such a chance to strike by declaring a state," Mr Nodal said.

And yet Mr Arafat cannot hold off indefinitely without appearing ridiculous to his own people. Many delegates to the PLO's central council - including members of his own Fatah faction - want him to declare a state next week, no matter what the consequences, because they have no trust in a process which has seen Israel consistently break promises to hand over territory, or release political prisoners.

Negotiations on a final settlement were scheduled to end by May 4 last year: "This interim period has already been extended almost 20 months," said Daoud Talhami, a Palestine National Council member. "We are afraid that any further postponement will make self-rule into a permanent situation" with Israel not taking negotiations seriously, he said.

The weekend meeting in Gaza has the veneer of democracy, but few think the council will do more than rubber-stamp a decision that is Mr Arafat's alone. In six years of self-rule in the West Bank and Gaza, the Palestinian leader has taken a personal interest in the most minute details of administration, holding back the maturation of institutions and the judiciary.

He will be guided this weekend by that same belief that he knows what is best for Palestinians, and by his concern for his own legacy - manifested at home by a ruthless suppression of Palestinian television and print media. At 71, Mr Arafat is determined not to go down in history as the man who betrayed the Muslim claim to Jerusalem, though he would dearly love to die as the first president of independent Palestine.

That was shown again on Thursday during an interview with CNN. "You have to remember, you are speaking to Yasser Arafat," he said when asked if he would compromise on the Haram al-Sharif, the Jerusalem site that has the third holiest shrine of Islam.

"I will continue to liberate all the Islamic and Muslim holy places," an agitated Mr Arafat said. "I can't betray my people. I can't betray the Arabs. I can't betray the Christians. I can't betray the Muslims."

He has also told the Israelis that he fears assassination should he give up the Islamic holy places in Jerusalem. Held sacred by Muslims, the 36 acres of the Haram al-Sharif is also revered by Jews as the site of their temple, destroyed in 70 AD, with the Western (or Wailing) Wall as its one surviving relic.

Palestinians argue that the Israelis and Americans have been unfair to describe Mr Arafat as inflexible, and lacking the courage for bold decisions. They say that he has regularly displayed such mettle as a leader - not least by entering into the peace process seven years ago.

The question of whether to abandon heartfelt claims in Jerusalem, said Bassam Abu Sharif, a long-time adviser, "is not a difficult decision but an impossible one for Arafat".

Bruce Gyngell, the Australian inventor of British breakfast television, who has died aged 71, was one of the most colourful, idiosyncratic and domineering of media pioneers. He was far removed from the grey-haired executives who have tended to control ITV television behind the scenes. Gyngell stood out even in an industry where media tycoons from Lord (Lew) Grade to Rupert Murdoch called the shots. His staff nicknamed him the "pink panther" because of his love for the colour he saw as life-enhancing: he wore pastel pink shirts, and had his office painted pink, with yellow sofas.

His 50-year career was packed with dramatic twists, spanning the start of television in Australia - his was the first face to appear on screens - and the introduction of sofa-style television to Britain. Gyngell is best known in the UK for his high-profile completion of the rescue of TV-am, a year after its disastrous launch in 1983.

The first commercial breakfast franchise had teetered on the verge of collapse, losing £500,000 a month, when in 1984 he was persuaded by his Australian colleague, the businessman Kerry Packer (who had taken a rescue stake) to sort it out. By 1986 it was ready for flotation on the stock exchange, and briefly flowered into the most profitable of television networks. This was achieved by ruthlessly targeting programme costs - and dumping the 1984 Olympics coverage. He made the station a place "of eternal summer so that the lost, lonely people could turn on and feel warm and bright" - it may have been naff, but it was effective.

He singlehandedly invented friendly sofa-style television and chatty presentation - although it was far from easy. The TV-am sofas were actually benches, to encourage guests to sit up, but upholstered to disguise the fact. Viewers felt they joined a surrogate family, with Anne Diamond playing the fresh-faced but smart girl from next door. The company, run from Camden Lock, North London, was moulded around Gyngell and his often faddish likes and dislikes.

Some thought him barmy, predatory, or worse. Employees had to fit in. But he encouraged newcomers into television: his former secretary, Ulrika Jonsson, was made the weather girl, to inject some cheer into forecasts. Gyngell broke the rules, and liked to pose as being outside the wasteful British television establishment, while always remem bering to court the powerful. One of his early fallings-out was with a talented rising executive, Greg Dyke, who had already set TV-am on the road to recovery with Roland Rat before Gyngell's arrival.

Gyngell, an outspoken believer in market forces, but with charm bordering on charisma, became Margaret Thatcher's favourite broadcasting executive when she was prime minister. When she complained about ITV being the "last bastion of restrictive practices", he endured a bruising technicians' strike from 1987-88 - more than 200 were sacked - but suffered a heart attack due to stress.

He wanted change in ITV to cut out waste, a redrawing of the regional network, a Channel 5 to provide more competition. But by 1988, he was already speaking out against a blind auction of franchises, recognising the destruction it would wreak. By a cruel twist, the highest-bidder auction that Thatcher introduced in the flawed 1990 Broadcasting Act ensured that TV-am's £14.3m bid was completely overshadowed by a rival offer from the GMTV consortium of £34.6m when the awards were announced in October 1991. TV-am, the company he had shaped and nurtured, was effectively destroyed.

But Gyngell had a final surprise up his sleeve. A day after the news broke, he was hosting the first (and last) TV-am journalism awards. There, he dramatically, almost as an afterthought, produced a handwritten letter from Thatcher. He read it out to the astonished audience. "When I see how some of the licences have been awarded, I am mystified that you did not receive yours and heartbroken. You of all people have done so much for the whole of television . . . I am only too painfully aware that I was responsible for the legislation," she wrote.

It was a sensation. The audience gasped, then applauded. Thatcher was saying sorry.

In true Gyngell style, he refused to be broken. He proceeded to hold the company together until December 31 1992, through sheer force of personality. The final morning's broadcast ended, at 9.30 am, with the station belting out You're Simply the Best as a photograph of everyone who had ever worked for the station was flashed on to the screen. It was a moment of high emotion, and great sadness.

Gyngell then hosted a champagne-fuelled farewell party with the sole founder-survivor, Sir David Frost, by his side. Yet, true to promise, the severance terms were very generous, and many of his multi-skilled, hard-working staff were snapped up by GMTV and the rest of ITV. Five years later, he had the bitter satisfaction of being proved right as the licence payments were slashed.

Gyngell always remained Australia's golden media boy. He was born in Melbourne, and inherited some pretty extraordinary genes. His great grandfather was the pyrotechnician for the wedding of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert, while his grandfather, who settled in Australia, introduced cider-making to the continent. His father ran a flying circus before becoming an engineer with Mobil, and his mother was of Irish extraction.

He attended the private Sydney Grammar School and briefly studied medicine at the city's medical school. But he took time out to work as a disc jockey for the Australian Broadcasting Corporation, joined the university air squadron and was desolate when the Korean war ended before he had a chance of action. He stayed at ABC until he was 22, when Sir Frank Packer, the newspaper tycoon took a shine to him and offered him a job with Consolidated Press. Packer then won one of the first two licences for commercial television. Gyngell fixed himself up with a two-year traineeship in New York.

At NBC and Columbia University, he fell in love with television, and returned to Australia: on September 16 1956, he opened Packer's network with the words: "Good evening and welcome to television."

In a 10-year stint, he made Channel 9 the most successful network. He got married for the first time, to Ann Barr, and had three children. But, in a pattern that was to repeat itself, he walked out of his job in a row over money and autonomy. He was wooed by the rival Channel 7, with more money and a Bentley - Gyngell loved the good things of life, and was always immaculately dressed.

Then he switched to Lew (later Lord) Grade's ATV in Britain, and backed such 1960s classics as The Golden Shot, Randall & Hopkirk (Deceased) and New Faces. Once again he took off when Grade refused to make him chairman. Back home in Australia, he was offered the chairmanship of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, started an ethnic aboriginal channel, and by the early 1980s had become absorbed with eastern ideas - Zen Buddhism, meditation and the Insight philosophy.

For much of his latter life he followed a macrobiotic diet - even when entertaining at the Savoy. He believed in the power of positive thinking. And he was always very superstitious. At the time of the franchise renewal, staff wore company watches and key fobs, and were supposed to rub them to channel positive forces.

This eccentric streak became ever more pronounced as the success of TV-am allowed him to dictate what went on. The call from Kerry Packer to sort out TV-am, which he had described as a "load of old crap", had made him the UK's highest paid television executive, at £193,000 a year.

In 1986, he married again, this time Kathy Rowan, a TV-am producer, and started a second family, with two sons, Adam (now at Eton) and Jamie. After the licence was handed to GMTV, he toyed with alternatives, but soon returned to Australia, to lick his wounds, and run Channel 9 for two years. He also helped to launch the first World Summit on Children's Television, now a regular biennial fixture.

But this familar maverick did not stay away from Britain for long. He bounced back in 1995, as chief executive of a bruised Yorkshire Television (in an odd double act with its chairman, Ward Thomas), later absorbed by Granada.

F or a man whose private language and jokes could be salty in the extreme, he then pulled another surprise, by turning into a moral guardian. Gyngell was appalled first by tacky late night ITV schedules, and then by a prime-time series, Hollywood Lovers, which had segments on the "mile-high club" and plastic surgery for genitalia. He refused to show these programmes in the Yorkshire region, and ran Whicker's World Turns Again repeats instead.

Two years later, as ITV companies converged, he went into semi-retirement, with homes in Chelsea and Dorset, but with positions at Channel 9 and its holding company, PBC Holdings. It was only in April 2000, as news of his illness spread, that the man who had made such an impact on British television was honoured with a fellowship for lifetime achievement by the Royal Television Society. Many thought it shocking that he had been overlooked for so long.

He is survived by his wife and five children: his son David and daughters Bryony and Sky from his first marriage, and his two sons from his second.

 Bruce Gyngell, broadcasting executive, born July 8 1929; died September 7 2000

On the day "company doctor" David James turned up to inspect his new patient, the assistant at the dome box office offered him an OAP discount. "I thought I looked about 18," James joked. "I work out in the gym every morning at 5.15 for an hour and a quarter. I'm in pretty good shape."

Like the 90 dying businesses he claims to have saved, there is not much fat on James. Nor - if you listen to those at the sharp end of those rescues - much room for sentiment either.

Though he claims to have saved 25,000 jobs, occasionally, as in the case of Dan-Air, the patient has not survived his radical surgery.

"We saw him as an undertaker rather than a doctor," said one union negotiator who dealt with him there. "He's bloody good but he's not a miracle worker. He is interested only in figures. Emotion, sentiment, compassion - I saw none."

James, 62, dislikes the "company doctor" tag , with its overtones of the ruthless surgeon, and prefers to be called a crisis manager. As for Dan-Air, he claims he saved some jobs and helped make Gatwick more than a "bucket and spade airport".

Unflappable

There is, however, a telling story about a photograph he keeps on his desk of the diving support vessel British Argyll, which almost sank one of his toughest cases, North Sea Assets.

"That ship was the last built at Smith's yard on Teesside," said James. "Any tear-jerking stories you ever hear about the poor workers of Sunderland do not take account of the dreadful manner in which that ship was built. It was supposed to be state of the art but turned out to be defective in every respect. It was supposed to be built for £12.4m but cost £42m."

What you must remember, one of his closest colleagues said, is that when "David comes in, more often than not, those involved haven't admitted the truth of the situation to themselves. What he does is blow away the bullshit.

"He is a pretty unflappable guy. David has stared down the barrel of a gun and held his nerve." Quite literally.

In 1986, James - who had been hired to rebuild the engineering group now called TransTec - flew to Tripoli to free a dozen staff working for one of its subsidiaries on a project for the Libyan navy. They had been taken hostage by revolutionary guards. But James was himself held for six days - while the Americans bombed the base, calling it a "legitimate terrorist target" - before negotiating the return of all the men.

It was through another gun - Saddam Hussein's supergun, and his key role in exposing it - that a decade ago James first made the transition from the business pages to the front pages. The affair also cemented his close links with the security services. As the Scott report into arms sent to Iraq makes clear, James did much of the legwork for MI6.

Assassinated

He first noticing the gun's three huge steel tubes, "the thinnest of which had a thumping great muzzle, like something from a strip cartoon siege gun", during a tour of Walter Somers' factory at Halesowen in the West Midlands.

A week after he passed his suspicions on to an MI6 contact called Mr Q, Gerald Bull, the supergun's Canadian designer, was assassinated in Brussels.

James later used his banking contacts to track down the rest of the weapon, which was supposed to fire anthrax shells into Israel, before it left Teesport docks. Part of this cloak-and-dagger operation involved him getting 900 documents from Walter Somers' offices which were photographed secretly through the night with MI6 equipment set up in a room at a Halesowen hotel.

With such a gripping CV, it is hardly surprising that he has been courted by more than one publisher for the story of his life.

He is not immune to vanity, and admits to have "a fairly large City fan club". The only son of a working class cook - born within a mile of the dome - he seems to have had a point to prove. "When I left school at 18 I did not go to Oxford because we could not afford the £1,500 it would have taken to keep me there for three years. Now I can earn that sort of money between breakfast and lunch."

Despite this unabashed self-confidence, there is something in his mix of candour, unshakable competence and quick dry wit which makes people instinctively warm to him.

Firefighter

When he was sent in to sort out Eagle Trust, the empire built by the convicted fraudster John Ferriday, Devon farmer Malcolm Simons complained he had pocketed £2.8m fees over six years. Sir John Harvey-Jones would have been cheaper, he said.

James replied that after deducting the cost of his office, secretary, car, driver, pension and other overheads he was left with "just" £1.5m. "I think you'll find he (Harvey-Jones) is even more expensive than you think I am."

He is certainly a safer pair of hands than his namesake, the equally expensive Aston Villa goalkeeper, nicknamed Calamity James. This David James has his own sobriquet, too - the City's Red Adair, after the Texan who tackles oil well fires.

Stories of his stamina and 80-hour weeks have passed into legend in the Square Mile.

He once worked non-stop for 48 hours at Dan-Air, and later in the space of a few days crisscrossed the globe between London, Hong Kong, Singapore, Bangkok, and back before booking himself into hospital for the night for surgery. He was at his desk the next morning, and rounded off his day with a three-mile run in Hyde Park. James is not a big one for holidays. "I have had the odd weekend in Venice but I have never had a proper holiday abroad. In business I have travelled so much that the last thing I want to do when I'm relaxing is to go a long distance."

That said, he has been known to fly to Sydney to see the whole of a Test match, and allocates himself three sacrosanct weeks a year off to pit his fabled powers of risk analysis against the bookies at Ascot, Goodwood and Cheltenham race courses.

Marriage though, never got a look in. "I never intended to be a bachelor," he said. "When I could have married I felt I was too poor, and when I had enough, I was too busy. Now I am too old."

So what drives this human dynamo to such Stakhanovite excesses in late middle age is something of a mystery.

He lives relatively modestly for a multi-millionaire, between a home in central London and one in Hove close to the cricket ground. Glyndebourne, the home of his other great passion, opera, is only down the road. (He turned around the English Symphony Orchestra just for fun after a major problem with funds). Even his offices in Victoria are "a bit of a broom cupboard". It is the sheer kick of salvaging the seemingly unsalvageable that appears to turn him on.

Asked why he agreed to take on the dome, when he is already chairman of the Robinson Group and a member of Lloyd's regulatory board, James fired back: "Like Everest, it's there. You've got to climb it."

Nor is he being paid, of course. A knighthood being worth so much more, presumably, and a peerage priceless.

America's preoccupation with other countries' long-range weapons is behind the design of a new anti-missile system, which congress is likely to approve for deployment later this year. In principle, it is temptingly simple. Hostile missiles blast off, fly round the earth, then come down again on target. All you have to do is intercept them after they have gone up, but before they come down.

In practice, it will be incredibly difficult. Earlier efforts to develop particle beams came to nothing, so the current schemes call for ground-launched missiles to catch the missiles. They will have to be more accurate than missiles have ever been before. The Pentagon reckons this can be done. Incoming missiles are likely to be moving at upwards of five kilometres per second. But the interceptors need carry no warhead. They can be smaller, lighter and easier to manoeuvre.

They would detect the incomers using a complex combination of sensors, based on existing technology. Ground-based radar and satellites with heat sensors would show up enemy missile launches. They would give a good enough prediction of their path to launch interceptors in the right direction. Then heat and light sensors would be used to control small rockets on the final stage of the defending missile and send it into high-speed collision. The enemy weapon would be disintegrated high above the atmosphere.

So far, so reassuring. But also much too optimistic, critics argue. The reason is that there will not just be the warhead hurtling through space. If the hostile party knows there are interceptors, they will modify their own missiles. Mounting a defence against intercontinental ballistic missiles assumes an enemy capable of building them and loading them with nuclear bombs. So it seems reasonable to infer that whoever it is, they can deploy counter-measures which would be technically simpler than making an ICBM in the first place.

And since an anti-missile system really has to be 100% effective, the advantage lies with the attacker. Up above the atmosphere, heavy and light objects follow the same trajectories. So it would be easy to make decoys which cluster round the nuclear warhead and confound the interceptor. A nuclear warhead is heavy and warm, but it would not be too hard to disguise it, cool its outer surface, or even make all the decoys resemble a warhead. The putative nuclear attacker also has the option of building low-flying, sea-launched missiles, or even smuggling the odd warhead to its target overland.

Unlikely, perhaps, but then nuclear deterrence has always traded on pretty unlikely scenarios. The anti-missile defence programme assumes an American president rejecting nuclear blackmail from a newly armed opponent secure in the knowledge that US cities are under a defensive umbrella. A little thought suggests that he or she can never be sure that the umbrella will not be leaky, or that the enemy strike will not come in underneath it.

Thirteen years after the Smiths broke up, Johnny Marr still fascinates: the 500-capacity Scala in London is crammed with punters, not to mention celebrities. Noel Gallagher is here (I thought Meg was the one who kept wanting to go out?), as is his brother Liam - together with current main squeeze Nicole Appleton. Bernard Butler of Suede you'd expect to see, but even legendary 1970s scene-maker Rodney Bingenheimer has come to check out the Healers, Marr's first band proper in more than a decade.

Against the sort of budget psychedelic backdrop usually seen in end-of-term school plays, the six musicians assume their positions. Despite counting in their ranks a son of a Beatle (Zak Starkey on drums) and a former member of retro-rockers Kula Shaker (Alonza Bevan on bass), it is Marr in the role of group leader that people have come to see.

He looks cool enough, despite being one month away from his 37th birthday, even if you suspect he probably made a better moody sidekick than a charismatic frontman. As to whether or not he can sing, you'd hardly know, because whatever comes out of his mouth is immediately swallowed up by the music (that the PA is so loud it's distorting doesn't help). The promotional CD doing the rounds, featuring a track called Last Ride, reveals a functional rock voice with, oddly enough, a tone reminiscent of Status Quo's Francis Rossi.

The first two numbers, Bangin' On and the aforementioned Last Ride, are impressive. In fact, if the Oasis songwriter wasn't such a close friend of his, you could almost imagine Marr thinking "Suck on this, Noel" as he unleashes wave after wave of pulverising sound. Because this sort of heavy psychedelic blues-metal (à la Led Zeppelin or the second Stone Roses album) is roughly what Standing on the Shoulder of Giants might have sounded like had Gallagher and Co managed to sustain the impact of that album's opening instrumental, Fuckin' in the Bushes. A contradiction in terms, perhaps, but this is stoner rock with energy.

Unfortunately, the rest of the gig presents mostly variations on that theme. Here It Comes and Caught Up are as pedestrian as their titles. During Down on the Corner, the Healers appear to be doing little more than jamming - filling up the periods when Marr is away from the mike with indelicate musical passages. Even fans of instrumental proficiency would decry the lack of finesse, the pointless reiteration, the bongo solos.

In a recent interview, Marr declared his intention that the Healers should be some holy union of T Rex, the Stooges, Santana and the Wailers, which is to suggest all manner of rhythmical delights and sonic tricks. He even intimated that keyboardist Lee Spencer (former collaborator of William Orbit) would bring a sense of electronic mischief to bear on the Healers' sound.

He doesn't - at least not tonight. Indeed, there is little acknowledgement of musical developments of the past 10 or 20 years. Ironically, Marr arguably did his best work since the Smiths with Electronic, his dance-pop venture with Bernard Sumner of New Order. No doubt he sees all his session-playing with the Pretenders, Roxy Music, The The and Kirsty MacColl as leading up to this. We always knew he had it in him: the desire to rock out, the musical equivalent of dumbing down.

Only the looped drum beat underpinning Voodoo in You changes the pace. The glam-metal stomp of Iggy and the Stooges' I Need Somebody provides a pleasant enough blow to the skull, but that song was so bound up in Iggy's mythos that tonight it is stripped of its meaning. Marr is no Iggy, no Dylan, no Lou Reed, no Neil Young. He will never transcend his era or face the fierce white light/white heat of critical significance again. He's just jamming.

The paradox of having a garden is that they are the best places for slowing down, but keeping them looking good involves more or less constant activity. This is not to say that some gardens aren't better than others at helping you unwind.

Ancient tradition thought of the garden as an oasis in the desert with walls to keep out the world and lush plants irrigated by sacred springs within. Broadly speaking, this is the basic plan of the Paradise garden, which persisted for centuries, and the idea of the walled garden as a place for relaxation - and, traditionally, erotic trysts - is one carved deep into the gardening psyche.

Niwa, the Japanese word for garden, means "an enclosure purified for the worship of the gods", conjuring up the idea of a quiet, protected place for peaceful contemplation; in this case, the atmosphere of calm is usually achieved by austere simplicity. But if you don't fancy this pure and Zen-like route to balance, you could still go for the design trick of a sense of enclosure, which is common to many traditions - a sanctuary that will be your own private domain.

In this respect, urban gardens are an ideal base to work from. They are often already surrounded by walls; and if not, then the small size of the average back yard for once is an advantage because it makes it easier and more affordable to screen it off with fences, trellis or climbing plants. Once you've got the sense of enclosure, then gateways, for example, become loaded with mental resonances, as well as being practical. Beds, borders and edgings then complement the picture.

Two designers from different backgrounds have both published books on the subject of the garden as a kind of inner sanctum. In The Inward Garden (Little, Brown, £27.50), the American Julie Moir Messervy, who was inspired by the traditional gardens of Japan, talks about seven primary elements of the garden - the grove, hut, enclosure, threshold, meadow, mount and spring - and how they can be represented in a small domestic space. A "hut" can be a garden bench backed by a tree, for example, or a "bridge" can be a simple granite slab over a rill, and still have resonance in a scaled-down landscape.

In his book, Portfolio Of Contemporary Gardens (Quadrille, £25), the British designer Stephen Woodhams shows how using symbolic elements - bleached stones and semi-succulents to represent a desert garden, for instance - can evoke a wider landscape, and how setting a garden apart both in time and space, and personalising it, gives it restorative powers beyond the pleasures of simply being outside doing nothing.

Both designers recommend water as the most powerful element influencing the atmosphere of a garden. The sound of a fountain trickling into a stone basin cools and relaxes, and the energy of water always seeking its lowest level is deeply satisfying, especially as a strong, constant flow.

Huge water extravaganzas, such as the Villa d'Este at Tivoli, the André Citroën gardens in Paris, or the amazing water chutes of the gardens of Nishat Bagh, in Kashmir, give the impression that you need a generous space and budget if you're going to use such features in a garden. But a rill a few centimetres wide, flowing down a set of six brick steps and into a small pool in a quiet corner of the Alhambra Palace gardens, in Granada, Spain, shows how the narrowest stream of water can add animation and life.

Still water works well, too. Pools, especially if they are sunlit, produce calming reflections that can be intensified if the lining is painted in a dark colour such as black or green. Always aim for a sense of abundance when using water, as in those swimming pools that gently overflow their edges.

Another designer, Christopher Bradley Hole, uses a rigid steel lining in pools, so that the water level is flush with the surrounding paving. But for abundance without building work, a beautiful, wide-necked pot filled to the brim and regularly topped up gives the equivalent effect.

One garden, in Catford, south London, shows how enclosure, water and simple shapes can work together to make a calm place without being a burden to maintain. The owners, Francis and Kirstin O'Connor, work irregular hours as a theatre designer and a doctor, and since their time off rarely coincides, they wanted to make sure they spent it relaxing rather than doing the gardening. With this brief, Andrew Mitchell, of the Vivid Space design group, built them a decking "stage" on which to eat out and entertain friends.

In answer to the question whether decking is suitable for the British climate, Mitchell points out that this one is made from English oak, which does not get slippery when wet. He has planed it for a smooth finish and nailed it to joists as you would a floor, using rust-free, stainless-steel nails, so it's solid like a boat deck.

The deck has now weathered to a silvery-grey colour, and is surrounded by raised beds of spiky phormiums, bamboo and, in summer, a hot border of purple basil and crocosmia; there's also a pond in one corner. The couple asked a horticulturalist friend, Simon Auton, for a planting scheme that would leave a few pockets of space that they could fill in with their own favourites. Auton tried to steer them towards having more space for plants and, in retrospect, Francis says it's the one thing they would do differently if they went through the process again.

This is a good compromise between being a slave to your garden and going for the minimalist "low maintenance" style that's high on concrete and Perspex, but low on live plants. And in any case, it's debatable whether this really does cut down on work. As garden designer Chris Maton says, "Though contemporary-style gardens are low maintenance in the traditional sense - low weeding and low watering - they involve more maintenance in the upkeep of materials. You end up treating metals, for instance, or cleaning glass. I always tell my clients that truly low maintenance is difficult to achieve."

There is a conflict in this talk of serenity-inducing gardens, because they inevitably involve getting the builders in. It's not ideal, but remember: after the work is done, you really don't have to do a thing, because if you really hate gardening, you can always get a gardener.

'I make the time,' declares Dr Demetrios Matsakis, 'so I can do what I want with it.' He's only slightly joking - if anyone runs the world's time, it's Dr Matsakis. He is Director of Time Standards at the US Navy's Directorate of Time - the hours, minutes and nanoseconds on the 60 atomic clocks at his laboratory in Washington DC provide the official source of time for the Department of Defense (and therefore the network of Global Positioning Satellites) and the standard of time for the US. He is the world's top time lord. And, today he's in the time centre of Britain - and no, it's not Greenwich.

It's been many years since Greenwich really made the time. If you want to find the clock capital of Britain now, you have go to Teddington, Middlesex, to the National Physical Laboratory (NPL), where Dr John Laverty and his team of eight scientists check the three caesium clocks that send out the national radio time signal from Rugby. NPL's signal is used by government and companies such as Railtrack (all station clocks in Britain are timed with NPL, 'although we can't make the trains run on time,' says Dr Laverty).

Under international agreement, world time actually comes together at Sèvres, just south-west of Paris, at the Bureau International des Poids et Mesures (BIPM). There, an average is taken from 200 atomic clocks in labs around the world. Each month, a report is sent back to the time labs such as NPL or Washington to let them know how close their clocks are to the average. 'If I'm 10 nanoseconds out, we have a problem,' says Dr Matsakis. However, as his lab provides 60 atomic clocks - approximately 40% of the world total compared with the UK's 3 or 4% - he can, of course, set the average. Why does it matter? GPS [Global Positioning Systems] satellites, for instance, are time-coordinated - and if one is even a nanosecond out, you could miss by feet.

It's certainly a weird career area. 'I was a real child of the space age,' says 50-year-old Dr Matsakis, who grew up with one eye peering through a telescope at the stars and has just been voted vice-chair of the prestigious International Astronomical Union's commission on time.

They get together every few months at time conventions to write equations on the back of napkins and discuss projects, such as 'redefining the second'. This is important because the world is not as exact as the atomic clock, and often moves faster or slower - at present, every so often 'leap seconds' are inserted into the year.

'The thing about time,' says Dr Laverty, at 36, a relative newcomer, 'is that everyone is so young - even when they're close to retirement'. They each have their own pet projects. For Dr Matsakis, it's 'finding the best way to average all clocks. It's the holy grail of time.'

NPL is now a 'GOCO' centre in the jargon of Whitehall, ie, Government Owned, Contractor Operated. The time has officially been privatised. But ask Dr Matsakis if the US Navy would sell off the time and he is adamant. 'No way,' he says. 'They need the time. Things have to work. If there's a war on they don't need some peacenik not giving them the time... ' Are they ever late? 'My personal timekeeping is pretty awful, actually,' Dr Laverty admits.

The Italian countryside is a regular holiday haunt for thousands of Britons - it's the slow tempo of life that draws visitors to the small sleepy towns. But for local people, things are moving just a bit too fast with the pace of modern living simply not leaving enough time for life's essentials. Now a nationwide campaign is underway to keep the 21st century at bay.

Orvieto is a city in no hurry. From its table-top position above the Umbrian countryside, it sits protected from the stresses of life - there has never been an earthquake, it's never been bombed and the city has never suffered a major fire. One of Italy's oldest cities, it attracts thousands of tourists every year, won over by its beauty and tranquillity.

But even here it seems, life is a beat too fast and Orvieto is fighting back. It's joining forces with more than 30 towns and cities across Umbria and Tuscany - in the Citta Slow or Slow City movement.

'A slowing up would improve the quality of our life here,' says Louisa Borgna, one of the leaders of the Citta Slow campaign. 'It's not that we don't want progress, but we want to try to control the speed at which things are moving.'

Campaigners say that the movement isn't fuelled by nostalgia. They don't want to be seen as anti-technology or scared of the future. They say it is about having the all- important time and space to enjoy life's pleasures. The Citta Slow movement is a code of conduct, a form of self regulation for Umbria and Tuscany. 'To be a Citta Slow, people must place an emphasis on respecting and preserving cultural traditions,' says Louisa Borgna. 'Using modern inventions like electric buses can help prevent pollution, and we'll use our cars less often, too. We should also make an effort to keep the town beautiful and clean.'

Residents are also being asked to grow sweet-smelling plants and flowers in their gardens to ensure the aroma and look of rural Italy is as idyllic as possible. The campaign has won the backing of local people keen to ensure Orvieto retains the charm so enjoyed by tourists.

The Foresi family owns a wine cellar in the main square, which was dug by hand underneath the city 700 years ago. Its owner, Gianluca Foresi, says, 'Citta Slow is about not concentrating on time. It's about enjoying every minute, every bite of each day.'

Born and brought up in Orvieto, Signor Foresi says Citta Slow is the best thing that could have happened to his home town. 'You can just sit in the sun and not worry about your work, your business, your problems and your troubles. You might say we're living in a fairy-tale.'

It's early Sunday morning in SoHo, and downtown New York is beginning to wake up. On the wooden benches in front of Jean Claude's, a restaurant so rough-hewn and thoroughly French that it might have been airlifted from Aix-en-Provence, bleary-eyed punters are sifting lazily through the mammoth New York Times.

Turning down Prince Street, Tan Dun, China's best-known contemporary composer, looks every inch the archetypal SoHo inhabitant. Despite just stepping off a long flight from Beijing, he looks rested and relaxed, ambling along in sandals with abrown paper bag tucked under his arm: "Not many Asian artists really love or even experience this kind of environment," he says, pointing out various "hot" galleries hidden behind the postindustrial facades of the buildings. "Of all of my generation who moved to the States, I am the only person really working and living in New York as a normal New Yorker. I don't have any distance with the local people here. The culture is my culture. This is my home..."

Yet Tan Dun's origins couldn't lie further away from this modish corner of Manhattan. Over breakfast in his minimalist white-on-white apartment, he slips a cassette into the VCR, a documentary account for Chinese TV of his recent research trip to Hunan, the rural district of China where he was born and spent his early life.

In the opening shot, framed against a lake and a traditional Chinese wooden pavilion, he announces: "The most important thing in our lives is always to keep thinking about where we came from. Only then will we know where we are going." He goes on to detail a childhood immersed in the "shamanism and magic" of a rural village, an adolescence toiling in the rice fields during Mao's Cultural Revolution and a musical background so suffused with Chinese folk values that until the age of 20 he had "never heard uttered the names of Beethoven, Mozart or Bach". The camera pans across jagged, mist-enshrouded mountains. It cuts to a lavishly costumed Taoist ceremony performed by octogenarian monks. The monks play "sheng" mouth organs, elaborate bamboo instruments that issue a dank, sweet whine, and "po" hand cymbals, which work up a delightful clatter. The finale is the "feast of 100 dishes", in which every family in the village brings along a course, and on the screen Tan, now tipsy on home-made wine, sings comically with the local schoolgirl choir.

Tan Dun's journey between these two contrasting worlds - Hunan Province and NY State, as far east and west as it is possible to travel culturally and spiritually - is perhaps one of the most extraordinary success stories in modern classical music. From what he says was a starting point of blissful ignorance of the international canon, Tan has now established himself as one of the most sought-after composers in the world. From entertaining peasants in the auditorium of the rice field, he has graduated to some of music's most prestigious venues: Lincoln Centre, Carnegie Hall, the Barbican.

The same global cultural contrasts are evident in Tan Dun's remarkably diverse body of music, which Japanese composer Toru Takemitsu has described as "violent as a burst of human blood, yet full of grace". From Hunan comes the palette of sounds and timbres, the traditional Chinese instruments and the incantatory, contorted vocal techniques, employed to powerful effect in works such as the ritual opera Nine Songs. From urban New York we get the hip-hop rhythms, industrial guitars and samplers that propelled his hi-tech, thrash-aesthetic reinterpretation of Peony Pavilion, the classic 16th-century kunju opera. Hunan again provides the philosophical underpinnings, particularly the Taoist view of art as "reverberations with the vital forces in nature". Meanwhile, from the urban wellspring of New York comes the pure spirit of downtown experimentalism so evident in Soundshape and The Pink. "What is very little heard in European or western music is the presence of sound as the voice of nature," commented John Cage, who was a huge influence on Tan's early US work. "It is clear in the music of Tan Dun that sounds are central to the nature in which we live but to which we have too long not listened. In Tan Dun's music, the east and the west come together as our one home."

Finally, from its sheer diversity, and the necessity of communicating to listeners perched on the very extremities of human civilization, comes Tan Dun's mass appeal. His Heaven Earth Mankind (Symphony 1997), commissioned for the Hong Kong handover, was made into a video for MTV. And his soundtrack for Ang Lee's Chinese-language film Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon - premiered at the 2000 Cannes Film Festival - has already shifted 200,000 copies in the east.

His place on the global music stage is confirmed by the Tan Dun Festival which opens at the Barbican on September 28. Entitled Fire Crossing Water, it will feature UK premieres of his new work Water Passion as well as the score to Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon.

However, the reaction to his work has been far from universally positive. Some Chinese composers have dismissed him as "not serious". The New York Times has printed scathing reviews, many of them by the music critic Bernard Holland, who has written: "He is like the proverbial boy locked in a pastry shop, gorging indiscriminately on everything around him." Tan Dun responds: "He says that I am always trying to mix wine and beer. I think he is crazy. Eventually we will all realise one day that there never were any boundaries, except those of man. All music is created by God."

But Tan's moments of solemnity are usually immediately undermined by a mischievous streak: "He's always been a spontaneously funny guy," says director Ang Lee, who has known him since the late 1980s. "Whereas most of the other Asians in New York were generally quite shy and reserved, he could keep you entertained for hours singing some hilarious Hunan village song about how the farmer was feeling up the pigs and stroking their tits." He is also an excellent raconteur: "Often you will find yourself going for lunch with Tan Dun," says Avril MacRory of the BBC, which co-commissioned his 2000 Today: A World Symphony for the Millennium, "and returning at nine or 10 in the evening."

However, Tan Dun's playful, imaginative ability to turn any situation into an entertaining anecdote has also earned him criticism. While his stories of shamanistic culture are voraciously devoured by those who have known him only in the west, many of his more cross-cultural acquaintances mutter about "exaggeration" and "embellishment". "Tan Dun is a completely urban person," says Zhou Long, a fellow composer who has known him since his early days at the Beijing conservatory. "He's not really from the village. He is from Changsha, the capital city of Hunan province. Sometimes, when you do promotion, you make stories. There is nothing wrong with that. If you are writing some biographical notes you can do that."

There would seem to be a certain amount of evidence to support this view. One example might be the Chinese TV documentary, which was shot not in his home locality but deep in the countryside, a plane journey away. The actual village where Tan Dun spent some of his childhood has long since been swallowed up by the Changsha suburbs. Tan Dun's reaction to these assertions is both conciliatory and indignant: "Perhaps they are right. Perhaps I am an urban person. I did spend some of of my time in the city. But anyone who says that I didn't also experience the culture of the countryside, then that is an insult to me and my background. They didn't come with me to live in a small village. They didn't come with me to be re-educated in the rice fields. How can they know how I lived my life?"

Tan Dun was born in 1957 in the central Chinese district of Hunan, the only son of Tan Xiang Qiu, a military officer in the People's Liberation Army, and Fang Qun Ying, then a doctor working in a Hunanese hospital. In the traditional manner, his first name, Dun, meaning "shield", comes last, though in the west he likes to be casually referred to as Tan. While his official publisher's biography - reproduced in most articles and interviews - cites the precise birthplace as the village of Si Mao, according to his father, Tan Dun was actually born in a military hospital on the outskirts of Changsha, now a rather grimy industrial regional capital of more than a million people. As was common Chinese practice for a busy working couple, his father and mother sent young Tan Dun off to live with his grandmother in the satellite village of Si Mao Chung, about 20 miles outside the city centre.

Tan Dun recalls the environment in the village as "very barbaric, very shamanistic, very mystic, very sacred, filled with traditional art forms, poetry and music... Like all the people of Hunan, the villagers were very secretive, very strange and completely devoted to their secret beliefs." It was this mystical environment, he says, that provided him with his first musical experiences, primarily through esoteric local rituals.

"From the local people, I started learning how to play Chinese folk instruments, bamboo flutes and the 'erhu' two-string fiddle. It was very natural. Music was simply part of life, in local kunju theatre or shamanistic ritual, mostly at weddings and funerals."

When he returned to the city, at what he says was the age of nine, his musical education continued when a teacher presented him with an decrepit old violin: "It only had three strings and as I had no money to replace it, I treated it like a three-stringed fiddle." By now, however, Mao's cultural revolution was getting into full swing and soon Tan Dun's parents were sent off to be re-educated in the countryside, his father by cleaning out the animal sheds on a farm, his mother to become what was known as a "barefoot doctor" among the peasants. At the age of 17, Tan Dun followed them to be re-educated in the rice fields of the Huangjin commune, about 50 miles outside Changsha.

Ironically, Mao's policy - which, Deng Xiaoping later said, caused "grave misfortunes" for China - turned out to be a real re-education for Tan Dun, who had now fully formed in his mind the ambition of one day becoming a composer: "In the daytime I would be planting rice in the fields for 10 hours, 12 hours," he recalls. "But in the evening I would direct all farmers in a kind of rural orchestra using their cooking pots and whatever else they can use. We had no money so most of our instruments were pots, branches of trees, bits of bamboo. I began also to collect many, many folk songs."

After two years of backbreaking work on the commune, by a macabre stroke of luck for Tan, the entire orchestra of the Changsha Peking Opera were drowned in a boating accident and officials were sent out to the communes to recruit trained musicians. He spent a year fiddling his way up through the ranks of the orchestra, then the death of Chairman Mao brought the cultural revolution to an abrupt halt. As traditional educational establishments opened once more, Tan Dun was among the 40,000 applicants for places at the Beijing conservatory, with 400 competing for just eight places on the composers' course.

The entrance exam lasted a full week and covered everything from mathematics to Marxist theory to orchestration and harmony: "I'd never been trained. I was little more than a farmer; I had never seen a piano or any of those fancy instruments. So I did everything according to my first instinct." On the final day came the aural: "The examining professor asked me to play some Mozart," says Tan. "And I said, 'Who is Mozart?' And he shook his head and said, 'Ohhhh my God!' And then he said, 'All right. Play some Bach.' And I said, 'What? Bach? I never heard of Bach.' And he said, 'What about Beethoven?' And I said, 'Sorry, I cannot. I am from Hunan; I don't know who Beethoven is.' So I suggested that I just improvise a little and he said, 'OK'. I took out my violin, which had only three strings on it, and I improvised for an hour. He was really shocked. Then there was a really big debate. And against every professor in the selection committee, he argued that I should be taken on the course."

This last anecdote is a particular favourite, repeated in various forms in interviews. Sometimes he improvises on his three-stringed violin for two hours, often as long as three. On other occasions he is even more versatile: "They asked me to sing," he told one publication, "and I could sing 300 folk songs from Hunan, Szechuan, Tibet, all over. They accepted me because I was a little shaman."

How much actual "shamanism and magic" really went on in the village where he grew up with his grandmother is far from clear: singer Chen Shi-Zheng, who also grew up in Changsha, contends that "every grandmother there is a shaman", but Tan's fellow Beijing conservatory students, some of whom grew up in neighbouring regions, cast doubt on this. Chinese shamanism is much more strongly associated with the north of China and Mongolia.

His father, Tan Xiang Qiu, confirms that it was in the village that Tan Dun's love of music was ignited and divulges that his son would continually play the violin "until the skin under his jaw was hard and callused". But in Tan Xiang Qui's account, his son returned to the city at the age of six, not nine as Tan claims, and he also paints a picture of influences rather less traditional and shamanistic.

According to Tan Xiang Qiu, far from being primitive or ignorant, his son's traditional formal musical education was quite advanced for provincial China at that time: by the age of 14 he had mastered Chinese notation and a little later travelled to Beijing to meet the com poser Hua Lu Bin, expressly for the purpose of studying western music. It is difficult to believe that this quest for western musical knowledge might not have included at least some mention of Mozart or Bach.

As for the infamous audition at the Beijing conservatory, the examining professor, Li Xian, who would go on to become Tan Dun's mentor, recalls none of the events or details mentioned in the anecdote; not the questions about Beethoven or Bach, nor the three-stringed violin, nor the one- to three-hour session of traditional improvisation: "Two hours? No, that would have been impossible," he says stiffly. "Each student was allocated a specific amount of time for the tests. The maximum would have been about 20 minutes."

While Tan Dun actually gave a rather lacklustre performance at a very straightforward audition, it was his sparkling piano trio, the evocatively entitled I Dreamt of Chairman Mao, based on traditional Hunanese folk music, that earned him his place at the conservatory.

So, in September 1978, he packed his belongings - "a bamboo pole over my shoulder," he says, "one side wrapped up with my clothes, on the other side my scores" - and left Changsha to join the composers' class. Almost immediately, Tan was marked out by the eccentricity of his musical vision: "He always used influences in his music from his own daily life," remembers Li Xian. "He would use in his music the voice of the stones, or something falling on the floor, or a cup being struck: noises normal people don't manage to use or even hear. If someone crushed a can of drink in order to put it in the trash can, he would replicate the action to hear the noise again. Then he would introduce that sound into his music."

After a visit in 1979 to China by a Japanese troupe who used traditional Japanese instruments to make contemporary music, Tan Dun began applying the same principle to Chinese instruments and music. One of the fruits of this approach was his first symphony Li Sao, inspired by a fourth century BC melancholic poem. The piece, whose title translates as On Encountering Sorrow, featured traditional instruments and caused some controversy. His next major work, the string quartet Feng Ya Song, came second in Dresden's Weber Prize, making Tan Dun the first Chinese com poser to win an international prize since 1949. The Dresden victory had an immediate effect on Tan's career, propelling him to the forefront of the "new wave" of Chinese composers, but his music was denounced by the state in its renewed campaign against "spiritual pollution".

Once the political storm had passed, Tan Dun made a request to continue his studies at Columbia, and permission was granted. So, in 1986, he took a flight from Beijing to New York and touched down in what would become his adopted homeland. "I took the subway from the airport to Manhattan," he recalls, "and I immediately understood that it wasn't at all the place I had imagined. I saw many people in the subway car, and they were all different colours. I asked myself, 'What country is this?' "

However, Tan soon tired of Columbia University. "I immediately wanted to get away from the kind of depressing, bitter, atonal, selfish and superintellectual post-post-whatever music I was being forced to write there." Columbia soon reciprocally tired of him, and the professors there display a simmering animosity towards him that continues to this day: "He was actually a very nice guy. He was a very good raconteur and I remember he was telling me stories from China that were perfectly human and very entertaining," says Columbia lecturer Mario Davidovsky. "But he was at that point enormously involved in promoting himself and his career. And he was much more interested in that than anything that might have been going on at the university."

As Columbia was only paying his fees, he had to earn money to live. "I worked in restaurants and played my fiddle on the streets of Greenwich Village. That was my biggest classroom and in some way it was very close to my village in China, with its ritual music and its religion."

At the first opportunity, he moved from the university dormitories into the basement of a brownstone in Chinatown, began to attend cutting-edge performance works and gradually became part of an artistic Greenwich Village set that included Steve Reich, Philip Glass and Meredith Monk. It was also about this time that Tan Dun first met John Cage and his music became, as he puts it, "Cagealised": "Though I had been using incidental noises and found instruments since I was living in the village, of course I never thought of it as avant garde. But he was doing what I had done in the countryside 20 years previously."

When Tan Dun decided that he wanted to launch himself into this world, he turned to his landlady, Mary Scherbatskoy, who had previously been a producer of dance. "He just asked me casually one day if I'd like to produce an opera. And he showed me the score, and it was quite astonishing. But of course, being Chinese he wanted a cast of thousands. Eventually, I got him down to nine." The piece, Nine Songs, also based on Chinese poetry, used traditional ceramic Chinese instruments and opened with an extended sample of Tan Dun's shamanistic wailing. It was a sensation when performed at the Pace Downtown Theatre in May 1989.

Tan Dun went on to produce a number of experimental performance-based and dance pieces: Soundshape in 1990 at the Guggenheim Museum, which included an entire village orchestra cast in ceramic, and The Pink in 1993, which included a cast of naked dancers playing instruments constructed entirely out of paper or cardboard. It was at the last of these, in which Tan Dun also performed as the naked conductor, that he first met his future wife, Jane Huang, then editor of a New York-based Chinese fashion magazine: "After the show we all went to a bar . . . Immediately, he began paying me a lot of attention - I had a stomach upset and he went to the trouble of trying to get the waitress to get me some milk. Then suddenly, he said to me, 'Would you like to come to Tibet with me?' I didn't know what to say, I was absolutely shocked. I had completely misheard the question and thought he said to me, 'Would you like to come to bed with me?' But in fact we did end up going to Tibet very soon afterwards. We wanted to get married in the mountains. It was a very quick romance." Because of laws barring overseas Chinese from marrying in China, they had to settle for a tower-block register office in Hong Kong. They now have an two-year-old son, Ian.

By this time, Tan Dun's reputation was beginning to cross over into the mainstream. An association with the BBC Scottish Symphony Orchestra was the catalyst for the Orchestral Theatre series, four instalments of experimental gimmickry (part II saw the audience join in with trance-like chanting) multimedia (part III was set against a newsreel ranging from the Beatles to Mao's revolution) and a full orchestral score. The Edinburgh Festival commissioned Tan Dun's phenomenal Marco Polo, which featured a "postmodern" libretto by New York Times music critic Paul Griffith in which Marco and Polo appear as two characters/singers representing the yin/yang, east/west boundaries of modern culture.

"I don't really have any great interest in the east and the west as a dialogue," Tan Dun says. "What I am interested in is trying to find a single language and distinctive style that is made up of many, many cultures and that can reach from many different diverse cultures." It is ironic that, in pursuit of this goal, he feels he needs to play up the primitive aspects of his background to such a degree, though in fact, the emphasis of his biographical details probably says more about the need for modern composers to distinguish themselves as much in their press packs as in their work.

However, Tan Dun will ultimately be judged not on his life story but on his music, and in this area he still has a great deal to offer: "One of the things I like about pop music is its accessibility and power. There, music just becomes the art of dancing together, performing together. And I think that if you can find that same international communicable quality, and somehow combine it with a very distinct personality and a very local and a very, very inward point of view, then you can smash the world."

Life at a glance

Born: August 8 1957, Changsha, Hunan, China.

Education: Beijing conservatory, 1978-85; Columbia University, 1986-89.

Married: Jane Huang, 1994 (one son, Ian, aged two years).

Operas: Nine Songs, 1989; Marco Polo, 1993-4; Peony Pavilion, 1998; Tea Opera, to be premiered in 2001.

Orchestral works: Li Sao, 1979; Feng Ya Song, 1983; On Taoism, 1985; Orchestral Theatre I-IV, 1990-1999; Death and Fire: Dialogue with Paul Klee,1992; Ghost Opera (with Kronos quartet), 1995; Heaven Earth Mankind (Symphony 1997), 1997; 2000 Today: A World Symphony for the New Millennium, 1999; Water Passion after St Matthew, 2000.
