France's fuel tax standoff escalated further yesterday as serious fissures began to appear in the ruling coalition and the European commission threatened legal action to maintain the free movement of goods.

With some 80 % of the country's petrol stations either empty, under tight rationing or reserved for the emergency services, taxi drivers became the latest group to join the campaign for fuel tax cuts, causing traffic chaos in more than a dozen cities with massed "go-slow" protests.

Farmers declared there was no prospect of them withdrawing from the barricades they are helping road hauliers to man outside 125 oil refineries and fuel depots around France.

Dodging riot police, several hundred farmers succeeded in blocking the entrance to the Channel tunnel at Calais late yesterday afternoon, leading to angry confrontations with motorists. The blockade was later temporarily lifted to allow furious British holidaymakers on to the shuttle.

Other farmers drove tractors and trailers on to train tracks outside Strasbourg and Bordeaux, bringing high-speed TGVs in the east and west to a standstill for most of the day.

Nantes, Nice and Rennes airports reported they had all but run out of aviation fuel, school meals went undelivered in the Vosges, emergency-only petrol stations went dry in Brittany, and police were called in to guard requisitioned pumps in Lyons.

For the first time in the four-day blockade, the French capital began to feel the pinch. While surrounding fuel depots were largely kept open by armed riot police, Paris petrol stations began to run out of fuel, particularly diesel, in increasing numbers.

Furious at the fuel tax cuts already offered to the road hauliers, the Green party, a minority member of the Socialist-led coalition, warned the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, that it would react "forcefully" if any more concessions were made to road users.

"I back the cabinet that I am a member of, but I want to remind everyone that I joined it on the understanding that we would work for clean air and for moving away from road to rail transport," said the environment minister, Dominique Voynet.

She had demanded an urgent meeting with Mr Jospin and said the Greens "were not in this government in order to do the exact opposite of what we were elected to do".

Mr Jospin said on Wednesday night there would be no further negotiations with the hauliers and the government's offer was final.

In Brussels, the European commission sent a formal request to Paris "concerning a possible obstacle to the free movement of goods", spokesman Jonathan Todd said. France would be violating EU law if it did not ensure its frontiers and main routes were kept open to goods traffic, he said.

Gordon Brown's closest trade union ally has accused his fellow TUC leaders of playing a "very dangerous game" by backing Britain's early entry into the euro, and thereby risking losing a promised referendum that could be won by the government by holding it when the time was right.

In a move reflecting the chancellor's determination to control policy on the single currency, Bill Morris, leader of the transport union, said the euro enthusiasts, who include TUC general secretary John Monks, were "running down the pound" and "preaching doom and gloom".

In an interview with the New Statesman magazine ahead of the TUC conference in Glasgow, Mr Morris insisted it should be the government that ought to "lead the debate on the euro", and he ridiculed claims that millions of British jobs could be lost by staying out of the single currency.

The chancellor has appointed Mr Morris to the court of the Bank of England, and, as if to emphasise the closeness of his view to those of the chancellor's, Mr Morris also published a Mori opinion poll showing a 10% net increase in the proportion of those prepared to back entry by Britain if the five convergence tests stipulated by Mr Brown were met.

Mr Morris's curtain raiser for the TUC euro debate next week - the chancellor will address the congress on Tuesday - was made as it emerged that Tony Blair has agreed to a formal structure of regular Downing Street meetings with the TUC for the first time since Labour returned to office.

In a sign of warming relations after what Mr Monks described as a "productive but patchy" first three years, there will be an official quarterly meeting between the two sides, backed with exchanges of position papers and a joint secretariat.

The arrangements, which supersede present ad hoc contacts, will also bring in other ministers when necessary, and follow moves for a more systematic relationship between the TUC and the trade and industry department under Stephen Byers.

But Mr Blair is still resistant to pressure from the unions to establish any broader tripartite "social partnership", bringing together government, unions and employers, as is common throughout the rest of the EU.

Although there are what Mr Monks calls "oases of tripartism" in Britain (such as the low pay commission and the health and safety executive) the government is reluctant to raise the spectre of 1970s-style corporatism as practiced by previous governments, though the TUC argues that use of such bodies can avoid the damage caused by "parallel lobbying" by unions and employers.

Mr Monks yesterday pointed to a "surge" of recognition agreements with employers as evidence that "unions now find themselves in the most favourable political and economic context for more than 30 years", although membership growth has been hit by job losses in manufacturing.

He also said that the TUC would press the Labour party to adopt three policies in particular for the next parliament.

It wants a legal obligation on employers to provide training for workers, the provision of company information and consultation rights for British workers, and complete protection of the terms and conditions of public sector employees whose work is transferred to the private sector.

The dome's financial director is expected to be sacked today. Labour MPs meanwhile joined the chorus calling for the head of Lord Falconer, the minister with ultimate responsibility for the fiasco.

Neil Spence, the accountant who has presided over the "black hole" in the dome's books, was waiting to hear of his fate from David James, the City troubleshooter brought in to keep the attraction open.

Lord Falconer, a commercial lawyer and close friend of the prime minister, was called an "endearing amateur" by Martin O'Neill, the influential chairman of the trade and industry select committee. There is also a growing belief among Labour MPs that even if he rides the present storm, he could be sunk by a national audit office report into the dome next month.

A spokesman for Mr James, who was highly critical of the lack of proper records of the dome's assets and contracts, said he "could not guarantee" that Mr Spence would survive his shake-up.

Mr Spence has already been in effect replaced by John Darlington, chief executive of the Robinson Group, whom Mr James drafted in to oversee the proposed sale to Nomura. The last part of Mr Spence's job, dealing with cash flow, has been handed over to an accountant from PricewaterhouseCoopers.

Mr O'Neill's carefully couched criticism of Lord Falconer comes as a major blow to his chances of clinging on. Even though Mr O'Neill stopped short of demanding his dismissal, he said a government minister from the Commons should now be put in charge of the dome to improve accountability.

"The lack of proper scrutiny and control over the spending suggests a naivety on behalf of the political masters of the project," said Mr O'Neill.

"They were not asking the right questions and addressing the issues as we expect. There is about members of the House of Lords in charge of important projects a sense of the endearing amateur, a sort of Lord Peter Wimsey."

Jeremy Corbyn, Labour MP for Islington North, went further. "I think the Prime Minister is protecting him because he's very close to him, because he's a friend of his, and I would think at the very least Lord Falconer should consider his position, and perhaps resign."

Even if Lord Falconer gets over these hurdles, he will have to weather the Commons public accounts committee, which will question officials from the dome, millennium commission and culture department on November 24.

Downing Street, however, rallied behind the beleaguered minister and said Mr Blair believed he was doing "a good job in difficult circumstances". A spokesman added that Mr Blair - whose family have yet to visit the dome - had no plans to visit the complex.

The Liberal Democrats, who have held back from calling for his resignation until now, piled on the pressure.

Spokesman Norman Baker said: "I am afraid that Lord Falconer must answer the calls for his resignation and go. He has overseen this project for two years and should have done far more to prevent what has now become a national embarrassment.

"The Tories must also take some of the blame. The idea of the dome was theirs. They created its shaky financial arrangements and insisted on the shroud of secrecy which has surrounded the dome ever since."

With the news that the dome's closing extravaganza was finally cancelled yesterday, even its most vocal supporter, the former Tory deputy prime minister Michael Heseltine, admitted serious errors had been made.

Mr Heseltine, who sits on the millennium commission which gave the dome an extra £47m on Monday, said it should have had the power to hire "a great entrepreneur with creative flair from the very beginning".

He accused his party leader William Hague of scoring "easy political points" for calling for the dome to shut now.

Mr Hague hit back: "It has become worse than a national embarrassment and it ought now to be closed."

The thorny issue of bonuses to the dome's directors took another twist last night, when a New Millennium Experience Company source revealed that he "did not expect anyone to get their full money".

Directors are entitled to bonuses of up to 30% of their total earnings at the dome and Jennie Page, who was sacked as chief executive in January, is thought to have walked away with her £150,000 bonus intact.

The bonuses will be decided at the end of the year by the board.

Yesterday it also emerged that the dome's sponsors, who played a key role in the sacking of Ms Page, would have sued to get their money back if it had closed early. "We all want the dome to stay open to the end of the year as it was supposed to," said a spokesman for Boots, which sponsors the Body zone.

When William Hague approached the podium in Birmingham on Tuesday to launch his party's latest policy document, Believing in Britain, he did so to an unfamiliar tune. Gone was the traditional Conservative party fanfare Land and Hope of Glory and in its place the strains of Man Next Door by Massive Attack boomed from the speakers.

To the party's image consultants it must have seemed the perfect combination for the modern Conservatives: the sound of urban Britain combined with a homely theme. There was just one problem - the band abhors everything the party stands for and yesterday announced that they would be consulting their lawyers.

"Massive Attack have not and will never support the Conservative party or their policies," the Bristol-based dance band said.

"If our music has been used by the Tories it is without our knowledge or our permission. The misappropriation of our music by any organisation or broadcaster will be dealt with in the strongest way we can."

A spokesman for the band's management company said: "The Tories couldn't have picked a worse band politically. Massive's political leanings are far more to the left than Hague, although I'm not sure they would give permission to any political party to use their music.

Last night Conservative central office was keen to play down the incident. "It's a massive attack over nothing," said a spokesman. "The music was for background and was not intended for broadcast."

The spokesman was unable to comment on whether Mr Hague is a fan of the band but said it was popular among staff at Smith Square.

Colombian police officers have found a 30m-long submarine, designed to smuggle cocaine, being built in a secret workshop 400 miles from the country's Caribbean coast.

Agents found the vessel in mountains near the Colombian capital Bogota on Wednesday. No arrests were made but documents found at the site show that the smugglers planned to transport the submarine to the Caribbean. Instructions on how to build a submarine, written in Russian and translated into Spanish, were found nearby.

"It sounds like a fairy story, but it is true. The drug barons are developing more and more sophisticated methods to ship cocaine," said the national police chief, General Luis Ernesto Gilibert. "The technology used was advanced."

Law enforcement officials say Colombian drug barons - who produce up to 520 tonnes of cocaine each year - are collaborating with the Russian mafia to exploit new markets in eastern Europe. However, a spokesman for the Russian embassy said there is little sign that Russian criminals are actively involved in smuggling from Colombia.

"It seems very unlikely. We have a much bigger problem with smuggling through Asia," he said. Police technicians estimate the submarine cost $5 m (£3.3m) to build. It is not the first "narco-sub" to be found in Colombia but it is certainly the largest, with accommodation for three people and a cargo bay big enough to carry up to 15 tonnes of cocaine.

In 1993, officers found a crude submarine in the Caribbean port of Santa Marta. It was used to smuggle shipments of 1.5 tonnes to Panama.

Fathers will be allowed to take two weeks of paid paternity leave under radical plans to give parents more time to care for their children.

The idea is favoured by a group of ministers examining ways of improving parental leave without antagonising business leaders.

Stephen Byers, trade and industry secretary, yesterday called on employers to recognise the importance of child caring. Many parents were trying to juggle "the responsibility of being a good parent with holding down a job", he said as he launched a consultation on changes to parental leave.

The government is to publish a green paper this year outlining changes to entitlements; giving fathers two weeks' paid leave after the birth of their child is expected to among the main proposals. At present they are entitled to 13 weeks' unpaid leave if they have children, up to age five.

Under the new proposal, the leave would have to be taken immediately after the birth to allow companies to plan for an employee's absence.

One ministerial source said the aim was to balance the demands of campaigners, who want fathers to be allowed to choose when to take their leave, with the needs of employers, who are wary of improving parental leave.

"A lot of people work shifts, and their absence has to be covered by someone else," the source said. "The people who are calling for a more flexible system come from the world of researchers and academics, who are a minority."

Ministers are likely to struggle to win the support of business for the proposal. This week the Confederation of British Industry called on the government to resist demands for paid parental leave.

Digby Jones, CBI director general, said his members feared ministers were planning new legislation on workers' rights in an appeal to Labour's core supporters before the election. "Enough is enough," he said. "We have had 16 pieces of employment legislation in two years. I hope Tony Blair and Gordon Brown will behave like statesmen and put the country first."

Mr Byers said the aim was to ensure that new measures were not harmful to business. "Particular attention will need to be given to the effect on small business."

The decision to keep rates on hold for the seventh month in a row may have been boring, but you can bet your life that the chat at yesterday's meeting of the Bank of England's monetary policy committee was anything but.

After last month's cliffhanging five-four decision in favour of "no change," the committee was probably just as divided over the rate decision yesterday. There will still have been those worried that private sector spending is not slowing rapidly enough to allow room for Gordon Brown's generous public sector spending plans to kick in, while the doves on the committee will have been cheered by a decline in earnings growth and a further easing of the property boom.

The joker in the pack has been the exchange rate. While sterling is testing seven-year lows against the dollar, the euro's tumble on the foreign exchanges has once again ratcheted up the pressure on manufacturers struggling to export to Europe. Because firms buy most of their raw materials and fuel in dollars, the current situation is the worst of all possible worlds, but from the Bank's standpoint the overall impact of the exchange rate is little changed since it last met.

The Bank declined to act last month despite its own forecasts showing inflation above its 2.5% target in two years' time. It would have been inconsistent for it to have raised rates yesterday after a month of conflicting signals from the economy. Doing nothing yesterday might have been boring, but it was the right thing.

Invensys sinks

Those who believe mergers destroy as much value as they create will be adding Invensys - the tie-up between Siebe and BTR - to their textbook studies unless a turnaround is effected pretty sharpish. The company yesterday reported trading difficulties in many of its core areas and, ominously, in software, where it has just forked out £470m to take majority control of the troubled Dutch group Baan.

Invensys' Canadian-born chief executive, Allen Yurko, blames an array of market difficulties - such as a slowdown in US residential building and a reduction in demand from the oil and gas sector as well as reductions in semi-conductor prices. Unsurprisingly, the City was sceptical of these claims pointing out that the US economy is booming, oil prices are rocketing and software sales are up everywhere.

Analysts accept that Invensys is sitting at the top engineering table where competition between Honeywell, Emerson and Schreiber is intense. But what value the merger of Siebe and BTR with the thousands of job losses and sales of businesses if it were not to make Invensys leaner, fitter and able to weather a storm?

So the markets gave Mr Yurko a serious clout on the head yesterday. A 37% share price fall in a Footsie company in a single day is almost unheard of.

One thing in particular which has stuck in the City's collective craw is the admission that software margins are being squeezed.

Having sold off businesses such as automotive products, environmental technology and aerospace operations, Invernsys faces a real question over whether it really needed to move into software. If it was an attempt to bring a bit of e-glamour to a business rooted in the old economy, it has all gone horribly wrong.

Stout surfeit

Are the Irish finally falling out of love with the creamy black stuff? It appears so, according to Diageo, which yesterday revealed that sales of Guinness had fallen in the Emerald Isle for the first time.

The 4% decline is hardly cause to sell shares in the world's biggest drinks company. But it does point to a longer-term trend - Diageo blamed Ireland's booming economic growth , which means "people are doing other things, rather than just going to the pub".

The problem, for Diageo is that Guinness has traditionally been the drink of the working man in Ireland. It hardly ranks alongside vodka and Red Bull as a trendy tipple for young, urban Dubliners or for the legions of employees of the country's burgeoning hi-tech industry.

In countries where Guinness has been introduced much more recently the drink is doing fine - because it is associated with Rutger Hauer's stylish marketing patter and with glossy advertisements showing horses bursting through waves.

Such a renaissance could take a while in the drink's home territory, where Guinness will always be the devil's buttermilk first produced by Arthur Guinness in 1759. Perhaps europhobes who want an example of the euro throwing an economy out of kilter and in the process doing serious damage to a country's cultural heritage should take up the issue.

Stephen Carter, the advertising executive who had been tipped to land the job of ITV Network chief executive, has instead accepted a job at cable company NTL.

Mr Carter will join NTL as chief operating officer from advertising agency J Walter Thompson. The agency acts for NTL and came up with the cable firm's slogan "technology tamed".

The appointment was viewed as a clear admission that the cable industry is in dire need of a bit of marketing nous. Cable & Wireless Communications, which NTL recently bought, is commonly among the most fiercely criticised companies in Britain for its poor levels of service.

Mr Carter's decision to accept the job at NTL is a further embarrassment for ITV which has struggled to fill its chief executive slot for nine months. He is reported to have turned ITV down two weeks ago.

The ITV job was vacated when Richard Eyre left to join Pearson TV in January and a succession of candidates have decided against joining the network at the 11th hour.

Others understood to have snubbed ITV include Richard Hytner, chief executive of advertising agency Publicis, Dominic Proctor, chief executive of Mindshare and Peter Littlewood of confectionary group Mars. The job carries a package of about £500,000.

Mr Carter, who was chief executive of J Walter Thompson, will replace Leigh Wood who the company said was standing down at the end of next March to spend more time with her husband and four children.

Barclay Knapp, NTL chief executive, said Mr Carter's background made him a good replacement. "His track record in building successful consumer brands comes at a perfect time in NTL's stage of development," he said.

Mr Carter had been at J Walter Thompson since joining its graduate trainee scheme after completing a law degree at Aberdeen university.

He became managing director of the London office in 1994 and took over as chief executive of the group, owned by WPP, three years later.

The case of the Siamese twins, Jodie and Mary, is a parent's worst nightmare. Jodie, according to evidence in the court hearings, is a "bright and alert baby, sparkling and sucking on her dummy"; her sister Mary's state is "pitiable" - she cannot even cry, because she has no lungs of her own. Mary depends on Jodie for her blood and oxygen. She is incapable of independent life but is slowly draining her conjoined sister, and unless they are separated, both will die within six months. The doctors in charge of the case want to save Jodie, which would mean killing Mary. The parents insist that God's will be done and that nature should be left to take its course. The only way to resolve the deadlock in this agonising dilemma has been to resort to the courts. Not surprisingly, the appeal court judges and the barristers admit to sleepless nights as they wrestle with the ethical and emotional implications.

Part of that perhaps arises from the sense that the law is not the right arbiter in this extremely unusual and delicate situation. The parents and the official solicitor acting on Mary's behalf have appealed against the high court decision for the operation to go ahead and the lawyers are debating fine legal points along the murky boundary between what is an unlawful killing and what constitutes "withdrawal of treatment". But the crux of this case is not to be found in such legal issues, but in a broader consideration of what is in the best interests of all - both parents and children.

It seems common sense that the right thing to do is to save one life, rather than lose both. But it is also common sense that the parents' wishes lie at the heart of the case. The Manchester hospital where the children are being treated has been inundated by members of the public protesting at the parents being overruled in the high-court judgment. Of course, in some cases we understand that parents' rights can be superseded by the state's responsibility to protect children's rights; for example, the state can overrule a Jehovah's Witness parent's refusal to allow a healthy child to have a blood transfusion.

But this is not such a case. In addition to the anguish the parents feel at one of their daughters dying and their own moral objections to this as devout Catholics, the benefits for Jodie are not even clear. There are serious questions about the quality of Jodie's life after the operation; the parents are certain that the health service in their home country and their financial situation would prevent them from caring properly for her if she was seriously disabled. They would perhaps have to leave her behind for fostering in England. In such circumstances how can the court enforce the operation even if it is ethically the right thing to do? After all, it will be the parents who will be left to carry the can. No, given the age and vulnerability of both the twins, this case has to be regarded as a question of private morality, leaving the state no right to intervene.

My god, I thought it would be so different. All so very different. Who will ever forget the sheer, joyous, fan-bloody-tastic feeling of mind-blowing exhilaration we all felt on that bright, confident dawn of May 2 1997, after New Labour had swept to power?

This is what I wrote at the time, as part of a text that is still studied in media courses around the land: "After 18 long, hard years, the forces of good have triumphed, sleaze has been vanquished and this poor benighted country has been instantly transformed.

"Under Tony Blair, no child need ever look plaintively up at a tree, unable to reach for that rosy apple.

"Under Tony Blair, no senior citizen at a supermarket till need ever fumble for loose change in an old coat.

"Under Tony Blair, no discontented youth need ever again perform an armed robbery on a sub-post office in order to be able to afford a brand new motor-scooter.

"Under Tony Blair, there will be no greenhouse effect, no BSE, no negative equity, no traffic snarl-ups on the M25, no deaths from drunk-driving, no feuds in Northern Ireland, no toxic waste, no increased bank charges and no inner-city kiddies under- performing in their GCSEs.

"Under Tony Blair, Britain will be transformed into a land of hope and plenty, a land from which we will all be filled with a new glow of confidence to march into a golden future. Hail Tony! Hail New Labour! And welcome, my friends: welcome to tomorrow!"

Reading this text today, over three years on, I have every reason to feel disenchanted. I had slogged my guts out for a New Labour victory, often talking until the early hours in other people's houses of the great benefits Tony Blair would bring not just the ordinary, decent people of this country, but those of us involved in the London media, too.

An end to parking restrictions on the north side of Upper Street. A revitalised ICA, with free access to early Tarkovsky movies to all people, regardless of race or creed, on the presentation of a birth certificate. An open invitation to dinner with Chris Smith for ongoing dialogue to encourage increased state funding for the arts. And - just as importantly - an end to disease, prejudice and poverty not only in the capital but in every city in Britain.

And now what? Or - to put it another way, a way that conveys just a small part of my anger - and NOW BLOODY WHAT?

For too long, I suffered in silence. When the Millennium Dome was built, I applauded it as a "soaraway success story - a fitting emblem for a new kind of Britain: efficient, forward-looking, popular and, above all, supercool". Why, I even found signs for optimism when hospital waiting lists grew longer. "It all goes to show," I wrote, "that never before has the NHS been so popular, so vibrant, and, perhaps above all, so supercool."

But I can hold my tongue no longer. No longer can I hold my tongue. It is my tongue that can no longer be held by me.

I have known and loved Mo for more than a quarter of a century now, ever since we both sat around on beanbags setting the world to rights, smoking what we probably shouldn't have been smoking and all to the radical, thought-provoking, but above all caring, sound of Justin Hayward and the Moody Blues. I suppose it was when I first witnessed her performing a miracle - she fed a gathering of up to 5,000 on no more than a handful of loaves and fishes - that I first realised Mo was someone rather special.

OK, the joint was pretty strong, and when I came down from it I realised there were in fact just five individuals in the room, each with his or her own portion of smoked kipper pté on ready-sliced granary loaf, but the point still holds: Mo is a lovely, lovely centre-left/left-of-centre person and fascist Tony and the rest of his spiteful, hardhearted control-freak cronies can ill afford to lose her from this administration or any other.

It could have all been so different, so very, very different. If Mo had been given the free rein she deserved, there would have been an end to all rows in government. Instead, the cabinet would have gathered not around a starchy table, but on the floor, with their shoes cast off any-old-how. The cabinet secretary would have placed some Marvin Gaye on the sound-system and they'd have come up with some really, really exciting ideas about the world and how to stop bad things happening and start good things happening, and it would have all had a really happy ending.

But now Mo's gone and it's never to be. And, believe me, I'm hurting.

Relatives of the 29 people killed in the Omagh atrocity broke down and wept yesterday as they watched for the first time horrifying amateur videos shot immediately after the Real IRA car bomb blast. The footage included sickening images of the dead and dying.

Several families left the inquest to watch the three videos, lasting about 10 minutes, in a side room. Their wailing could be heard outside, and they said afterwards that the sounds of screaming on the footage were as upsetting as the gruesome pictures.

Greater Belfast coroner John Leckey is presiding over the inquest into the deaths of 29 people, killed when a 500lb car bomb went off in the Co Tyrone town on August 15, 1998. It is expected to last four weeks, and yesterday was the second day of the hearing.

Only a short clip of the first video to be shown yesterday has been screened on television news. None of the rest of the footage has been shown.

Michael Gallagher, whose son Aidan, 21, died in the explosion, said: "I thought at first how could someone stand there and video a scene like that. Now I am glad they did. The opportunity should be given so everyone can see it, so that they can see the true horror of Omagh."

Mario Radford, whose son Alan, 16, was also killed, said: "When I saw the videos. I could not believe one human being could contemplate such destruction on another. It makes me angry these people are walking the streets. I have never felt anger or bitterness, but I do want justice.

"It was my solicitor who pointed Alan's body out to me. I was very near him. I don't know how I couldn't find him. I would probably have ended up in a mental hospital if I had."

The first film to be shown depicted an injured girl, aged about 13, wandering in a daze close to the bomb scene. She was crying: "Where's mummy? Where's mummy?"

The background sound of screaming was constant, and a badly injured woman, her face bloody, staggered about in shock. Her hands were raised and she constantly cried: "Oh my God. Oh my God."

As several people crouched over one victim, a man desperately instructed them on first aid. He said: "Keep the pressure on it. Hold pressure on it. Hard. Keep pressure on it."

One of the dead or injured was shown being carried away in a tattered red tarpaulin. A little girl was being helped to an ambulance.

The second video had a commentary from the man filming it. He had an Australian accent. He said: "You just would not believe this. You just would not believe what has fucking happened. The centre of the town had been wrecked by a fucking bomb two minutes again, less than that. You would not fucking believe it. So much for the fucking peace process."

His video was filled with the sound of crunching glass underfoot. At one point a woman shouted: "Somebody help me. Somebody help me."

Mr Leckey said the video was important because it showed that a water mains had been ruptured. That hampered the rescue, because victims and body parts moved under the force of the water.

In the third video there was a glimpse of the remains of a body, looking like a slab of raw meat. There was also a severed leg, partly covered in a bin-liner. In both cases, the operator quickly averted his camera.

One woman was lying on the ground alongside another, comforting her. The victim was motionless.

The camera swept along a bus used to ferry the injured to hospital. They had a catalogue of bloody injuries, and were in shock. One girl, her back terribly ripped, was supported by two friends. She lolled as if unconscious.

One man said: "Look for bodies. Keep your eyes going." Another muttered: "They were only doing their shopping." A third said: "Terrible. Terrible."

Patsy McElhatton, 59, a member of the Fintona cycling club, shot one of the videos, believed to be the third. He had his camera with him because of a club event.

Mr McElhatton said outside the inquest: "I was down at the scene less than four minutes after it went off. I knew a lot of people there, and, as I was filming, I was wondering why am I doing this? But I thought at least this will be shown around the world, and people will know what a bomb can do."

He had handed the video to police, after considering getting rid of it.

Mr McElhatton said: "The full horror of it all only hit me seven weeks ago. I won't walk down that street anymore. I wish I was never there, to tell you the truth."

The Police Federation in Northern Ireland announced it was appointing counsel to represent all of its members appearing at the inquiry. The move follows tough questioning of police witnesses over their reactions to the three confused bomb warnings, and has divided the families.

Michael Mansfield QC, appearing for Lawrence Rush, widower of Libby, 57, and Barry Fox, an Omagh solicitor representing the families of victims Esther Gibson, 36, and Avril Monaghan, 30, and her daughter Maura, 18 months, have led the probing. They are focusing on police procedures.

Ken Duncan, a solicitor for the family of Deborah Anne Cartwright, 20, who also died, objected. He wanted the questioning halted until the officers' legal teams arrived, and, after debate, the video evidence was taken.

Mr Leckey will rule this morning on whether he will subpoena Francie Mackey, the Omagh-based chairman of the 32-County Sovereignty Movement. It is believed to be linked to the Real IRA.

The United Nations yesterday evacuated virtually all foreign employees of international organisations and many local staff from Indonesian West Timor, a day after three UN workers were murdered by pro-Jakarta militiamen.

The Indonesian president, Abdurrahman Wahid, who is in New York for the millennium summit, blamed his political opponents for orchestrating the crisis to embarrass him. The Indonesian military, which did little to intervene during Wednesday's attack in the town of Atambua, tried to play down the incident, saying it was "a local brawl that got out of hand".

Four battalions of Indonesian army reinforcements prepared to head to West Timor in a bid to restore order yesterday, as the UN flew its workers and staff of international non-governmental organisations to safety in Bali.

"We left Kupang [the regional capital] for the airport in a convoy of 101 people at 5.30am," said Andrew Harper, programme coordinator for the UN high commissioner for refugees in West Timor. "We had a military and police escort and there were police at all the major intersections."

These precautions were deemed necessary following widespread rumours that the militia were heading for Kupang from Atambua. Residents of the town were visibly worried yesterday. A woman said many people were packing up and preparing to head to the hills, or out of Timor, if the situation deteriorated.

Another 69 people, mostly local staff of international organisations, crossed from Atambua into East Timor with the bodies of the three murdered UNHCR staff, said Mr Harper. "There will be another flight tomorrow from Kupang for the remaining 50 national and two international staff still there," he added.

In Jakarta, the Indonesian security minister, Susilio Bambang Yudhoyono, said 15 people had been arrested in connection with the attack on the UNHCR office and the ensuing riot. Another person had been arrested for the murder of a militia leader the previous evening that allegedly sparked Wednesday's rampage.

The Indonesian military, elements of which are widely accused of actively supporting the militias in West Timor, seemed less concerned by their failure to protect the UN staff. "What happened was just a local brawl that got out of hand," a senior spokesman, Air Marshal Graito Usodo, told a press conference.

President Wahid did not share these sentiments. Speaking on the sidelines of the millennium summit in New York, he said the Atambua incident was the latest episode in a protracted campaign to topple him. "This happened when I am here in New York, at the UN, to embarrass me."

Mr Harper disagreed. He blamed the government for not disarming the militia and separating them from the approximately 130,000 refugees from East Timor who are still camping in squalid conditions, one year after the militia forced them out of their home land after East Timor's overwhelming independence vote.

"The authorities do not have control in many areas," he said. "What happened [on Wednesday] demonstrates clearly that they cannot guarantee our security, even though they promised to last October." Then the Indonesian government signed a memorandum of understanding with the UN, promising to provide sufficient security for humanitarian workers and to ensure that the refugees had safe access to them.

In the last year the militia, a mixture of pro-Jakarta East Timorese paramilitaries, West Timorese thugs and members of the Indonesian military, have attacked and intimidated almost half the refugees into staying in West Timor. In the last few weeks they have focused mainly on intimidating the UNHCR staff, who are responsible for organising the repatriation to East Timor.

The chances of the US president, Bill Clinton, securing a Middle East peace settlement receded yesterday after the White House admitted he had failed to make any progress in talks at the UN millennium summit.

Mr Clinton held separate discussions with the Israeli prime minister, Ehud Barak, and the Palestinian president, Yasser Arafat, on the fringes of the summit. The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, said he could report no progress on the contentious issue of control of Jerusalem and that no further meetings were planned.

Time is running out for Mr Clinton, with the US presidential election only two months away and Mr Barak's coalition government facing collapse next month.

More pressing, Mr Arafat and his colleagues will meet this weekend to decide whether unilaterally to declare Palestinian independence on September 13, as they had threatened unless a deal was in place. The Palestinian delegation said the declaration could be delayed.

Mr Clinton had been desperate to secure a Middle East settlement as the main legacy of his presidency.

He met Mr Barak and Mr Arafat on the upper floor of the Waldorf-Astoria hotel in an attempt to see if there was a compromise that would complete the deal almost secured in July at Camp David. But White House officials said the positions had slipped back since then.

Mr Arafat, in his speech to the millennium summit, took an uncompromising stance, declaring that Palestine should have sovereignty over Arab east Jerusalem, ditching the possibility of a compromise that might have seen the city share sovereignty or come under international control.

Mr Arafat told the summit that the Palestinians had already made painful sacrifices for peace.

An Israeli official said nothing could happen in the peace negotiations until Mr Arafat demonstrated he was ready to discuss ideas offered at or since Camp David.

The public mood in Israel swung from anticipation to gloom yesterday after President Clinton failed to break the deadlock.

The acting foreign minister, Shlomo Ben Ami, warned against over-optimism at the prospects of reaching a peace agreement while Mr Clinton remains in power.

The mood darkened perceptibly as Israeli negotiators said there was no further room for manoeuvre with the Palestinians." We cannot be more flexible in our stances regarding Jerusalem," Gilead Sher, a negotiator, told Israel's army radio.

Although the focus of negotiations since the collapse of the Camp David summit in July has been the status of Jerusalem, Mr Ben Ami emphasised that there were wide gaps between the two sides on refugees, as well as on less contentious issues like borders and settlements. "We should not make the mistake of thinking that some symbolic compromise that Arafat agrees to on the Temple Mount solves the rest of the problems," he said.

Harvey Hinds, who has died aged 80, was a clergyman, youth worker, educationist and leading Labour local government politician. His superb organisational and people skills - frequently exercised behind the scenes - came to the fore during the years 1967-83 when he was chief whip of the often volatile Labour group on the Greater London Council.

When the long-time Labour leader Sir Reg Goodwin resigned in 1980, Hinds recognised that the next administration would need to respond to the massive social shift which had taken place in London during the 1970s upheaval: he desperately wanted a change from the old-style Labour leaders who paid more attention to officers than to their elected colleagues.

Following the 1981 election, with a majority of just nine, the Labour Group was split - left 22, right 18 and centre 10. Wanting a leader who would give a clear lead and implement change, he saw the best hope in Ken Livingstone and a new generation of talented young politicians, rather than a continuation of the old guard.

With Illtyd Harrington, as deputy leader, Hinds used his influence to lead the vital centre block of votes into the Livingstone camp to create an administration which was to change the face of politics in London.

But with numbers so tight, there was always the risk of the right voting with the Tories on occasions. Gradually, the tensions within the Labour group began to subside and, as Ken Livingstone was the first to recognise, this was largely due to Hinds' work as chief whip in managing to defuse the complaints of the often outraged right about the latest left-wing proposal.

Politics came into his life relatively late. Born into a Worcester fruit-growing family, he blossomed as a scholarship boy at King's School, Worcester, where his wide-ranging interests included singing in the cathedral, and he became head of his house. An exhibitioner at St Edmund Hall, Oxford, he read French and German before changing to philosophy, politics and economics.

The priesthood was always anticipated, and graduation was followed by two years at Westcott House theological college, Cambridge. But thoughts of a comfortable rural parish were cast aside following a chance invitation to visit the Charterhouse Public School Mission in the backstreets of Bermondsey, South London. The conditions in the area and the lack of opportunities for its youngsters opened his eyes.

From 1944-58 he was assistant missioner at Charterhouse, and then warden of the Wellington College Mission in East Lane, Walworth. These were pastoral roles with an emphasis on running youth clubs and taking children out to the greener suburbs to practise sport, and to camp in the grounds of Charterhouse and Wellington schools, and to the Isle of Wight - often their first glimpse of real countryside and the sea.

In 1958, Hinds moved round the corner as rector of St Peter's, Walworth. There he immersed himself in the local community, opening up the crypt as a social centre for local families. His insistence that local children should have local facilities led to the creation of the massive Burgess Park in Walworth, which he was asked to open in 1982.

Hinds' expertise in youth and educational issues led to membership of the team responsible for the Newsom Report - Half our Future - of 1963, on educational provision for 13 to 16-year-olds. Finding a natural home in the Labour party, Hinds's political life began with election to Southwark Council in 1960 and to the Greater London Council in 1967. It ended with the abolition of the GLC in 1986. He was chairman of Southwark's children's committee and of the London youth committee.

He was vice-chairman (1967-70) and then chairman (1970-77) of the schools committee of the Inner London Education Authority, a key player in the controversial reorganisation of secondary schools along comprehensive lines and in the devolution of some local budgetary control to schools, years ahead of the Thatcher government's proposals.

Though Hinds became an honorary canon of Southwark Cathedral in 1969, his political activities and achievements had confirmed his frustration with the church's inability and lack of desire to change social conditions, so he left it in 1972 to become chief executive of the London Union of Youth Clubs, which supported leaders in over 700 clubs.

The wide-ranging umbrella of the GLC also allowed Hinds to pursue other interests. It brought membership of the South Bank Theatre board (overseeing the birth of the National Theatre), the board of London Festival Ballet and the Port of London Authority. Hinds' year as ceremonial chairman of the GLC, 1983-84, saw the staid reception rooms and the wonderful riverside terrace of County Hall opened up to all Londoners, rather than just the "great and the good".

Abolition of the GLC in 1986 allowed a total life change and retirement to the Hertfordshire village of Tewin, where Hinds was a familiar figure with William, his beloved Airedale dog. There, he created a magnificent cottage garden.

Married twice, he is survived by his second wife Lin, and by Anna and Jeremy from his first marriage.

Harvey William Hinds, politician, clergyman and youth campaigner, born August 29 1920; died September 1 2000

If the opinion polls are correct and the elections fair, Slobodan Milosevic has less than a month left as Yugoslavia's president - and the candidate tipped to beat him is a rare animal among the Serbian elite, a man who never joined the Communist party or accepted favours from the present regime.

This unusual record in a centralised country where careers rarely advance without loyalty to the ruling party belongs to Vojislav Kostunica, leader of the Democratic party of Serbia. The latest figures from the Centre for the Research of Alternatives put him at 52%, against Mr Milosevic's 26%. Two other recent polls gave him a lead of more than 20%.

Mr Kostunica's success is all the more extraordinary, given that he is a low-key professor of constitutional law who admits that he has none of the fashionable requirements of modern electioneering. "I am not a presumptuous man and I do not think that I am charismatic at all. I am not a populist either", he told a press conference in Belgrade this week, according to the text his party put out on its website (www.dss.org.yu).

His attraction may be that he is the exact opposite of Mr Milosevic in character. He prides himself on being approachable and trustworthy. His campaign posters say: "Who can look you straight in the eye? Kostunica".

He is also helped by rare unity among Serbia's many opposition parties which back him. Only the Serbian Renewal Movement led by the maverick Vuk Draskovic has put up its own candidate.

The elections were called by Mr Milosevic a year early, after he rushed through constitutional amendments calling for the president to be elected by direct popular vote instead of by the parliament. This would allow him to run for two new four-year terms. He hoped to wrongfoot the the opposition, but the polls suggest he may have miscalculated.

The opposition and most independent analysts assume that there will be poll fraud, unless Mr Kostunica is ahead by a huge margin.

The opposition candidate traces his ancestry to a hamlet called Kostunici in central Serbia. This region, known as Sumadiya, where two uprisings against the Ottoman empire began, is the heart of historic Serbian nationalism.

On the stump he appeals to nationalist pride, evoking local heroes who fought against Serbia's occupiers. In Zajecar, on the eastern border with Bulgaria, he told a crowd: "Everyone in Serbia has some heroic blood. We will show how worthy we are of our ancestors on September 24."

Aged 56, he is a lifelong anti-communist, a moderate Serb nationalist and an economic liberal. He was among Belgrade University staff who were sacked in 1974 for opposing constitutional changes which gave Yugoslavia's republics and Kosovo substantial autonomy.

After Tito's death he co-authored the first book which was allowed to be published advocating a multi-party system. Six years later he refused to take his job back at the university when Serbia's new leader, Mr Milosevic, offered it.

Instead, Mr Kostunica took up the political fight against Mr Milosevic and joined other friends in forming the Democratic party. They were elected to the federal parliament. Three years later the party split over whether to co-operate with Mr Milosevic, and Mr Kostunica took the radicals with him to form the Democratic party of Serbia.

Although a strong supporter of the rights of Serb minorities during Yugoslavia's dissolution, he was never involved in paramilitary activities.

"In parliament he was one of the best speakers. He's honest and keeps his word. He does not seem obsessed by power, as most Serb politicians are," a senior journalist said.

One of his main promises is to change the Serbian constitution towards a parliamentary system. He then says he will resign after 18 months and hold new elections.

In foreign policy he is trying to steer a line between strong criticism of Nato and opening Serbia towards integration with Europe. He denounces western sanctions and welcomes French hints that they may be lifted after the poll.

He wants closer ties with the Serb-run entity in Bosnia. His attitude to Serbia's sister republic, Montenegro, is ambiguous. While he says he would accept an independent Montenegro, he has irritated its government by accusing it of being afraid of democracy in boycotting the elections.

In Kosovo he has close links with the Serb leaders in northern Mitrovice, who want to turn their part of the city into an enclave. He sneers at the US administration for relying on Mr Milosevic as a guarantor of peace in Bosnia and then denouncing him as a war criminal. He jeers at Mr Milosevic for pretending he won in Kosovo when his policy ended in "capitulation".

Denied access to the state television and radio, Mr Kostunica has campaigned in small towns. "Most people can hardly make ends meet. They are humiliated and tormented," he said. "Now they have raised their heads."

His big problem is whether Mr Milosevic will let him win. Mr Kostunica puts the issue in apocalyptic terms: "These are not normal elections. It is a matter of life and death."

What their papers say

"We have to win against Nato. We need people of granite to be our president, as President Milosevic is - hero of the country's defence and the man who launched renewal and rebuilding"

Borba [Struggle] - federal government newspaper

"Our proven enemies, Nato and the opposition, are working together. Their goal is further destabilisation of the country, economic torture and fragmentation," said Veselin Stanojevic, JUL board member, in the village of Vojnik

Vecerni Novosti [Our Newspaper] - federal government controlled

"While every honourable citizen was happy for every bridge, road and house that has been rebuilt, the opposition Nato parties compete in convincing our citizens that rebuilding and progress are just illusion and tricks," said Mirko Marijanovic, vice-president of Serbia

Politika [Politics] - main state organ

Massive support for beloved leaders is more important for [the Milosevic regime] than the individual thoughts of citizens hidden by the curtain at the poll booth

Danas [Today] - Non-government newspaper

Six years ago, I learned that my husband was having an affair with a woman 30 years his junior - one of a series of long-standing relationships with leading ladies in his amateur theatre group. After counselling, I decided to stay with him and asked him to leave the theatre, which he did. Redundancy led to his retirement at 55. I continued to teach full time.

Since then, he has done nothing more than attend a 20-week recreational course in philosophy, deal with the supermarket shopping and cut the grass. I've suggested voluntary work, study, part-time work and travel, but he spends his time in bed and reading. He is bored, and thoroughly bad-tempered, partly because of a sleep deficit resulting from the early stages of prostate cancer diagnosed three years ago, and partly because my work prevents my being lively company to divert him. He claims leaving the theatre has "fettered his mind" and left him incapable of wanting to do anything but return and play King Lear. Is this really the only future? How can I accept calmly his return to temptation?

Time to stop nagging

Don't you think it's time you took the blinkers off? As a former teacher myself, I know how narrow and small-minded teachers can be. The theatre offers all the fun, colour and excitement that you do not. You have laid the law down and made him leave it, offering in exchange educational courses and voluntary work. Ageing and ill as he is, and probably afraid that he might not have much longer, he probably doesn't see much point in those activities. There's no wonder he's depressed.

He has made an effort to accede to your wishes. He obviously regrets it and is not behaving very well, but he is waiting for you to do your part. The first thing you should do is stop nagging and start asking. Why does he need all these affairs? And why only the leading ladies? Is he even telling the truth? Having counselling for just yourself is hardly going to help you as a couple.

As to future temptation (and at 61, with all the physical effects of prostate cancer, it is increasingly unlikely) why not encourage him to return to the theatre, and go with him? Amateur companies always need behind-the-scenes workers - prompters, stage managers, props, wardrobe, scenery painters, committee members etc - which call for the organisational skills that all teachers possess. You might even discover that you enjoy it, too, which will create a new bond, and keep all those voracious leading ladies at bay.
Clare Girvan
Exeter

Go your separate ways

What a miserable existence your husband must be leading! And really, what a mean-minded, self-centred person you come over as! I found your letter one of the worst advertisements for conventional marriage I've encountered in a long time.

Significantly, you never once indicate that you actually love your husband. Why, therefore, do you want this charade of a relationship to continue? For that matter, why does he? Perhaps he has become more dependent because of his illness; perhaps he always was a dependent sort of man.

My recommendation to you both would be: free yourselves up. Get out from under one another's feet. Any meaningful relationship between you is probably over because love has gone out of it. Sticking together the way you are now isn't going to help either of you. At the very least you could bear in mind some of the things that were said in last week's Private Lives about the possibilities of a "platonic marriage", or another form of relationship.
R M Love
Glasgow

Get yourself a toy boy

How old did you say he was? Thirteen and a half? Have you contacted the Guinness Book of Records about this marathon sulk? Buy the silly old goat a bottle of Grecian 2000, send him back to his play-acting and carry on with your life. You'll hardly notice any difference.

For your recreation, may I recommend the acquisition of a toy boy? They are widely available, decorative and amusing, not to mention useful around the house, disposable and easily replaceable. Look for the label "Sauce For The Goose... "
Carla Randle
Crewe

You can't lock him up

The man forced offstage will not be in bed reading for much longer if he is wise. How absurd to make a loved one stop what they love to do. If she really thinks he does not still "play" on the side, then she is a fool. You cannot lock someone up and expect them to be happy. If love and trust were ever present at all in the relationship, there would be no need to ask another to be miserable.
